Taiwan has always created difficulties for Australia due to the attitude of China that Taiwan is part of that country and could not be dealt with on a government-to-government basis in any negotiations we have had to establish a trade post there through the chamber of commerce.

Here again we find we are having to create within our legislation the ability for the IASC to actually negotiate with any region that is part of a foreign country. So we are giving at least some tacit admission to the fact that we still perceive Taiwan as part of China, but that we can deal with it separately. One can view that in various ways. Taiwan is quite clearly a country standing on its own two feet in many ways and dealing with the world in that fashion. If it ever becomes part of China that will be a decision of the residents of Taiwan. Nevertheless it is probably a practical way of developing a very important market for Australia, particularly in terms of inbound tourism, and the coalition accepts the need for this particular device.

The next move is to streamline application and evaluation procedures. Section 7(3) of the act requires the commission to make capacity allocation determinations according to criteria set out by the minister for transport in policy statements issued under section 11 of the act. The bill proposes to empower the minister to issue abbreviated criteria that would apply in situations where there was no need for the commission to undertake the full assessment process. This would include the following situations: where capacity was unlimited under a particular bilateral agreement, for instance, the Australia-New Zealand route; where no submissions were received opposing the allocation of capacity; where only one application for capacity was made; or where an application for capacity was opposed but not under all of the criteria. That seems reasonably sensible.

Clause 9 of the bill would allow the commission to permit carriers to transfer their capacity rights to their wholly-owned subsidiaries. The proposed amendment would rectify an anomaly in the current act which forced Ansett to create a new company, Ansett International, to run its international operations.

The act currently requires the IASC to invite public submissions whenever a carrier applies for a determination to vary its capacity. The commission would, as a result, be required to call for public submissions if a carrier wished to hand back a portion of its entitlements. Section 12 of the bill would remove the consultation requirement for reviews in which the only effect of the varied determination would be to reduce the capacity allocated to the carrier.

One of the other areas is operational decisions in special circumstances. Put simply, the bill would permit the department to approve minor and temporary operational decisions without reference to the IASC. The scope of the department's authority would be delineated by regulation. Obviously, the coalition would always take an interest in those regulations to ensure that the purposes of the bill were maintained.

There is also the final segment, which deals with the internal processes of the IASC. The bill includes a number of miscellaneous provisions intended to streamline the day-to-day operations of the commission. The proposed new sections would permit the commission to deal with two or more matters in the same determination; allow the commission to operate with only two of its three members present; tighten the provisions in the act relating to the disclosure by commissioners of their pecuniary interest; and reduce the administrative costs associated with publishing determinations. All of those matters are eminently sensible, although one might wonder what would happen with only two commissioners present if they held differing views. Obviously, the purpose of having three is that there would always be a two to one decision one way or the other, but presumably this operation will occur as in this very place, where there are expected to be no contentious issues arising. I assume the department has made some provisions to ascertain the circumstances before it allows that situation to arise.

There is no doubt that the major airlines are in favour of things which tend to reduce difficulty for them in conducting their business, and that is always to be encouraged. In fact, one of the great problems associated with so many of our trading activities here in Australia, as we pointed out with the ANL situation, is that we tend to burden sections of our own community by too much regulation—for example, in the local tourist industry, in the way that people get here. We must always remember that, whilst we might be protecting the interests of Qantas and its one private shareholder, British Airways, and in the future presumably a number of other shareholders, by giving them privileged rights, we certainly do not necessarily do that for the hundreds of thousands of people who necessarily gain their employment by servicing the local tourist industry. We continue to create preferential treatment in certain segments of industry at the expense of all the other components.

That is very clear in the case of ANL. It is the only reason that we sustain cabotage on our coastline. As I pointed out in the parliament yesterday, that is precluding Western Australian grain growers from assisting to alleviate the effects of the drought and benefiting from the current circumstances here on the eastern seaboard. It is just silly to suggest that our local sea transport system is so costly and inefficient that it is cheaper to bring grain to starving livestock in the eastern areas from North America than it is to bring it from Western Australia, not to mention the associated quarantine problems that can occur with importation.

It is very silly to use a system of licensing of this nature to make sure that the airlines prosper when, occasionally at least, through that process we put up barriers to the prosperity of our tourist operations. That has always got to be considered, and I trust that that will be fundamental to the determinations of the IASC. I might add that the government has overridden what otherwise might have been the determination in terms of the extended activities of Air New Zealand, admittedly in participating in the domestic routes. Again we have an attempt to prop up the value of Qantas, the international carrier, with determinations and breaking of international agreements, for the simple reason that the government wants to sell it and get extra value for it.

That is a very short-sighted view in a couple of respects. I do not think the prospective shareholders will be caught by that particular proposal. They are going to demand some guarantees as to Qantas's domestic rights before they revalue the property. They will want to know that this arrangement is not going to cease the minute they have paid their money. Moreover, if that promise were given, we would be denying internal tourism within Australia, we would be denying business the best competitive price domestically.

Competition has been proven time and time again to be the only effective determinant of price. Of course, in that situation it always comes to the point where those other components of the industry which are far bigger and employ far more people can prosper. If we make it too expensive to get around Australia, either international tourists will not come or they will visit a single destination. We are well aware that many in the Asian region do not want that sort of tourism. They typically want to move from place to place and they need to do that in a package which is competitive with what other international destinations offer. When buying a ticket to fly to Paris recently, I was offered three free internal trips. That was the way the company got business; it got me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excellent deal.

—It was an excellent deal—provided by Air France on this occasion. This designated international carrier could not get within a bull's roar of it. Might I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is time that we members of parliament were given more opportunity to benefit from competition in this regard. I find it outrageous that when I am travelling I am often confronted with the fact, as on this occasion, that I have to find $15,000 out of my own bank account to pay up front for the privilege of getting the best price on a trip to Europe to carry out my parliamentary duties. Had I chosen to pay Qantas an extra $2,000 or $3,000 the government would have paid it direct. Of course, it would have had to come out of my pocket because there was a limit to what the government was prepared to provide me for my travel.

PARA.TAB: I find that quite outrageous. I find it doubly outrageous when I am forced to go there and say, `I have got a first-class ticket negotiated at a price of $8,000 or $9,000,' wherever I am going, and I am told, `Our price is $12,000 or $14,000 but I tell you what'—wink, wink, nod, nod—`we will book you through at $8,000 or $9,000 business class but we will upgrade you to first class.' You eventually find yourself somewhere overseas where you have lost all power of debate and someone tells you first class is full up and you had better sit where you are ticketed.

I am fed up with the concept of seeking privilege at a check-out counter. I am prepared to pay my way, provided I get the most competitive price. If that gives me a first-class ticket, I am entitled to it. I refuse point-blank to be offered this upgrade option. I find it demeaning and it is doubly wrong when some other carrier is prepared to give me that trip at that price. If it is happening to me as a member of parliament, it is happening to the general public. As I say, the major losers on that on in-bound tourism are our local tourist operators. People take other options. Mr Speaker's office should be looking at the rights of members in this regard and telling them that they can book where they like. We certainly should have the opportunity of at least two airline offices on the Senate side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Qantas pay any rent in Parliament House?

—That would be a nice question for the government spokesman to answer as to whether Qantas even pays any rent here. I presume Aussie does. They get a substantial privilege but the greatest privilege of all would be to confront a member and say, `Yes, you have the right to go elsewhere provided you can find the up-front payment before you get a refund.' That, of course, is a total discrimination. Many members, be they rich or poor, usually do not have that sort of money lying around in their bank accounts. In fact, they would be unwise to do so. It is just an example.

PARA.TAB: Air New Zealand, an international carrier, is subject to the legislation we are dealing with today. It was outrageous and stupid of the government to break off that international agreement. Many of its constituency will be the big losers from that. People in Australia are moving in large numbers from the south-eastern states in search of work. They are going to Queensland and to Western Australia.

Since the Court government has taken control of our affairs in Western Australia, it has had the lowest unemployment rate in Australia. Great projects are coming on stream—as long as this government's Aboriginal land rights act does not prevent them. A flood of people want to invest in Western Australia and they are creating much needed jobs. People are coming from the eastern states to take up those jobs.

Those people leave behind elderly relatives, friends and associates. The market in airfares should be highly competitive to give those people—who frequently are good Labor voters—the chance to visit granny or others. We like people to come to Western Australia because so many of them are so impressed with the place and its opportunities that they then want to become permanent residents. We welcome them because we are demonstrating how well a state can progress under a Liberal administration.

Those people's chances of doing just that have been reduced, at least marginally, by the government's decision to remove a viable competitor. As we learnt, it is no good trying to license companies such as Compass Airlines—as great a job as it did in creating competition—because starting a greenfields operation against the established majors is just too difficult. The only way to get true competition is to have another major on the route.

Air New Zealand was willing and able. It took the honest and principled decision and let Ansett come onto its domestic routes, at great savings to people. That is what we are here for. We are here to deliver better and more competitive prices. We get lectured on competition policy—the Hilmer report—every day of the week, but this does not seem to apply to Qantas or to ANL. Surprise, surprise! Who owns them? The Commonwealth government does.

It is an amazing situation that competition is a very good idea according to this government, provided that it does not have to participate. The government is going to prop up ANL and Qantas. It will do anything rather than apply those principles to its own operations, which need it very much.

I am reminded by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) that an airfare of $800 return is currently available to fly to Hong Kong. That price is not available to fly around Australia. It is not available in our own country. The government missed a great opportunity to help the people of Australia and to further develop our tourist industry which, by any measure, is a greater contributor to government revenue and to the national economy than one single airline, whatever the colour of its tail. I make that point very strongly.

The opposition does not oppose the legislation. We give it our support, but I sincerely hope that there is enough in this legislation to, if nothing else, give the IASC some courage to tell the government what is really needed to create a tourist industry in Australia that is not specific to the profitability of certain airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I comment on the International Air Services Commission Amendment Bill, it is probably useful to rebut some of the remarks that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) made. He obviously had a short speech which was given to him by somebody else and he had to add a little bit to the end to take up some time. The member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and I do not make long contributions, for we are intelligent enough to sit down when we have made our points.

PARA.TAB: As the member for O'Connor knows, the reason the government pulled the plug on Air New Zealand proposals was that Air New Zealand had not complied with the memorandum of understanding. That is the truth of the matter and the member for O'Connor knows that. The member for O'Connor, of course, gets up in the House day in and day out and lectures the government on how we should keep to the letter of this and to the letter of that, but when it suits him on this issue he says that Air New Zealand should be allowed to get away with only coming part of the way to the agreement that it had with the government.

As soon as Air New Zealand does its part, it will be able to implement the memorandum of understanding. Part of that is that it has to harmonise the customs and pre-visa clearances, and it would be ridiculous for us to allow Air New Zealand into the Australian market without that being done. The result of that would be a gaping hole in Australia's visa system and very little control over entry of people into Australia.

The member for O'Connor, who seems so supportive of Air New Zealand, obviously has not been to New Zealand for some time or he would see that pre-customs clearance advantaged people who wanted to fly Air New Zealand. At Auckland airport the service is a lot better through the terminal for an Air New Zealand flight than for a Qantas flight. I do not know whether that is helping competition or not or whether that is advantaging one player as opposed to the other. So the member for O'Connor ought to look at the facts rather than the fiction that he wants to establish.

What the government has done in the competition area is endeavour to get as many new entrants onto the trunk routes as possible but also put pressure on both the major operators in Australia to lower prices. Honourable members will have seen that there has been a significant reduction in prices in recent years on the major trunk routes in Australia.

We are having a little discussion in other parts of the parliament at present about whether we just want to allow competition willy-nilly by letting anybody into the race. One of the problems with airlines, in particular, and also with long distance coaches, is that if those industries are to have the confidence of the travelling public the safety regulations have to be pretty strict. The member for O'Connor ought to think about some of those matters before he just jumps in at the deep end.

We ought to address ourselves to what this bill is about: refining and streamlining the International Air Services Commission's process in recognition of the commercial imperatives under which airlines in Australia operate.Members might recall that the commission was set up in 1992, following the announcement of the One Nation statement that Australia would adopt the policy of multiple designation of international air services.

That has been a dramatic change from the past in that Qantas was the only international designator in this country, and we have now widened that specifically. That has had the effect of allowing more than one carrier to operate routes in and out of Australia. It brings the benefits of increased competition and, as the member for O'Connor said, stimulates inbound tourism and trade. An essential part of that process is that the commission was given a statutory responsibility to issue determinations which allocate air service rights to the various Australian carriers.

We should all recall that tourism is one of Australia's greatest exports, that all those dollars that come in from inbound tourism add very dramatically to the balance of payments for this country. Tourism also provides employment in those parts of Australia where there are not the same attractions that the major capitals offer. Tourism has become a very good mechanism for providing regional employment and in providing employment in many areas which are targeted at young people. I remember our former colleague, John Brown, who was the minister for tourism, saying that no-one is ever going to be able to invent a machine that will make a bed. In the hospitality industry there are jobs that cannot be replaced by mechanisation and computerisation. It is a very good industry for expanding employment.

One of the things that has increased inbound tourism has been the recognition by the government that we would have new entrants among the Australian flag carriers. Since the commission's establishment, it has played a very important role in ensuring the success of Australia's new aviation policy. Over the past two years, it has handled a heavy workload, and has managed the difficult task of balancing commercial airline interests against the broader national interests in what all would agree has been a highly professional manner.

The highlights over the past year have been the commission's determinations in allocating capacity to the Japan, Hong Kong and Korea routes. The capacity was allocated to Ansett, as a new entrant on these routes, and an additional capacity was allocated to Qantas, which is the incumbent carrier. Ansett began services to Bali, in Indonesia, in September last year. It is currently operating six services a week there. In September, Ansett commenced full-scale international operations with a Boeing 747 service to Japan and Hong Kong. Ansett now operates five 747 services a week to the new Kensai airport in Osaka and three Boeing 747 services a week to Hong Kong. From the end of October this year, the company also had the right to operate a Boeing 747, equivalent to 1.2 units per week, to Korea.

In addition to the allocation of passenger capacity, the commission has also made an allocation of freight capacity to a new entrant, which is National Airlines, on the New Zealand route. The commission's determination, allocating capacity to Ansett and National Airlines, has increased competition on the routes on which those airlines have introduced services. That is of benefit to both exporters from here and importers from New Zealand. It benefits that one market which we are trying to create between Australia and New Zealand. The sooner Air New Zealand fulfils its obligations under the memorandum of understanding, the sooner we will be able to expand that market in passenger capacity. Proportionately, New Zealanders constitute the largest number of tourists coming into Australia, whilst more Australian tourists go to New Zealand than do any other nationality.

That trans-Tasman route should be one where there are low fares, in order to encourage movement between our two countries. I have always held the belief—which is anathema to New Zealanders—that ultimately there ought to be some stronger union between Australia and New Zealand. The New Zealanders came to the Federation conferences at the end of the last century and, unfortunately, decided that they did not want to proceed. But New Zealand is the only other country that is taken account of in our constitution; there is provision in the Australian constitution for a union between Australia and New Zealand. As we improve the economic and transport links between our two countries and improve the movement of people between our two countries, I hope that those developments might eventually foster the idea that we should come a little bit closer in political as well as in economic areas.

I suppose that is like asking people from Melbourne to like Sydney-siders. The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was pretty keen on belting out the fact that people in the west are a bit different from the people here on the east coast. I think there is a lot of merit in developing a closer unity between New Zealand and Australia, and anything that drives down prices on the aviation highway between here and there is a good thing.

The commission's determinations and decisions have been made with a view to increasing inbound tourism and international trade and bringing benefits to Australian consumers by reduced airfares. Apart from the commission's determinations and decisions allocating capacity, the commission has also conducted a detailed assessment of the business plans and service proposals of a number of prospective start-up airlines, particularly the routes to Japan, Greece and the Netherlands. Two of these routes have a business orientation and one is a great familial destination.

It has always struck me that there is a need for more capacity to Athens. To my mind, it is a sorrow that Qantas stopped flying to Athens some years ago. A large number of Australian citizens who return to their former homeland for holidays or for family matters have been inconvenienced by that. If they want to fly Qantas, they now have to travel to London or Frankfurt and make an on-connection. In the main, they then choose to fly Olympic Airlines. That is revenue that is lost to an Australian carrier. The sooner we get another carrier on that route the better. From talking to the people in my electorate—they might give me a bit of a biased sample, because I think I have the largest Greek community in Sydney—I know that if there was an Australian carrier on that route they would certainly patronise it, as they did Qantas when Qantas was on the route.

The results of the commission's deliberations during the last financial year have seen it allocate more than 25 Boeing 747 equivalent units of capacity on routes to eight countries. These allocations provide for an additional 10,230 seats per week between Australia and these countries, increasing total capacity allocated to Australian carriers on the routes by more than 40 per cent. Those airlines were all making money, so obviously the capacity was there to be taken off other international carriers flying into Australia. When we look at that Pacific route, which is probably one of the best serviced routes in the world, with high class, high capacity aeroplanes, I think there is room for more Australian entrants to do the job of bringing tourists to this country.

Looking to the future, the commission currently has under consideration applications for capacity or reviews to determinations on 13 routes. The commission has clearly achieved an impressive outcome during the two years since its inception. I think all members of the House will support the bill as it will build on the good work that has already been done. I note that the opposition has said that it will support the bill. The changes that are outlined in the bill will lead to a more efficient delivery of the government's reforms in the aviation industry and will benefit the airline industry as a result.

The amendments proposed will introduce as much flexibility to the process of allocating aviation rights as possible, whilst retaining the need to apply proper public benefit tests where appropriate. That is one of the tests that is being applied on the New Zealand route—that there is a framework that both sides agree to. When the New Zealand party fulfils its side of the obligation, then it will get the traffic on the Australian routes. We cannot allocate these rights willy-nilly; we have to apply a public benefit test. We are allocating a government licence and, while it is a licence system rather than a free-for-all, a public benefit test should always apply.

We are trying to provide less burdensome and time consuming procedures. The changes proposed will assist the aviation industry's ability to respond to new commercial opportunities, while, from the government's point of view, they will place less pressure on the commission's limited resources.

Importantly, in the lead-up to the Qantas float next year, the changes proposed in this bill will provide Qantas with greater certainty regarding its rights and entitlements. That will enable the Qantas board to approach the public with the confidence that it should be able to, in ensuring that it gets the maximum public benefit for the taxpayers of Australia through that float.

I think the commission has done a good job. It has done it in a lean administrative way. There seems to be a fair amount of goodwill between the commission and the carriers. There have been a couple of unfortunate incidents whereby a carrier was given an allocation and still has not taken off, but I think that is probably a commercial reality in times of tight money.

I think that this is a sensible way for the government to allocate capacity to carriers other than Qantas. It has also ensured that we have got over the anomaly we had in the past, whereby there were a number of routes that Australian airlines were able to fly on but, because Qantas was the only designated international carrier, those routes were never used. The route to Athens, in particular, is one of those.

What the government has put into this system now is a level of flexibility that will allow other entrants to make commercial decisions about whether they think they can make a buck on that route, rather than what used to happen. Qantas used to make a commercial decision—that it could not afford to buy another aeroplane, that it did not have the capacity or that it wanted to redeploy the aeroplanes it had to some more profitable route—and we had routes that people wanted to fly along on Australian airlines, with no Australian carriers running on them.

One of the things that we should be promoting in international travel is the idea that one's visit to Australia begins at the terminal in the country one is leaving. We should be encouraging as many people as possible to travel on Australian carriers when travelling to Australia, so that they begin to get that flavour as soon as they leave home. Having more entrants will expand our capacity to do that. I think that this process has done nothing but add good to the industry, so I commend the bill to the Committee and I thank the opposition for its support of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would the opposition not support the International Air Services Commission Amendment Bill? It was opposition policy for the last federal election. I do not say that in any silly sense, but to point out that there have been some difficulties identified with the operations of the IASC since its inception in 1992. There is no doubt that the government's amendments are designed to make sure that the full flexibility of the IASC is achieved, and that the role of the IASC is clearly defined in future years. I think that that particular organisation is going to have a very busy existence. I was delighted to see that the government did pick up some of the suggestions that we were making and, indeed, the ideas that we would have implemented in government had we been elected last year.

PARA.TAB: One always has a period of settling down, and the IASC certainly had a period in which it was really finding its feet. In the original design of the commission there was a lack of flexibility, and there was some red tape that really did not allow it to meet the demands of the aviation industry with the speed that the industry obviously wanted. I said just a moment ago that the IASC is going to be a very busy instrument in coming years, and I think that is correct for a number of reasons, not the least of which is the tremendous growth of tourism in Australia and, indeed, the projections of future growth in international tourism, especially around Asia and the Pacific rim.

When groups such as the World Tourism and Travel Council estimate that by the year 2000 there will be 140 million Asian people travelling offshore for their holidays each year, it is to be hoped that Australia would get better than one per cent of that particular market. If we are looking at adding that sort of figure to our inbound tourism, we are going to have to have a tremendous lift in the capacity of airlines in and out of Australia during the remainder of this particular decade. Obviously, we all want to see Australian carriers participating in that.

That is what the IASC is all about. It is about allocating space and making sure not only that we have the capacity to look after the two existing carriers but also that the possibility of future carriers coming into the Australian market is not going to be stifled. With 140 million Asian travellers, if we got 10 per cent of that traffic into Australia—and there is no reason that we could not—we would have to triple the capacity operating into Australia today.

We talk about the tremendous advent of the third runway in Sydney but, quite frankly, we would have needed Badgerys Creek much more quickly than that. There would be tremendous demands on airports such as Brisbane and Cairns and, certainly, on those of some of the other cities. That is the magnitude of the task that Australia is going to have to face over the remainder of this decade, if we are going to get our full and fair share.

The IASC is going to have a busy time, in as much as the very nature of international airline operations is changing. We are seeing this now in terms of the privatisation of Qantas. British Airways has gone in as a 25 per cent stakeholder in Qantas and there is no reason to doubt that British Airways will be the largest foreign stakeholder in Qantas, once it is off the government books and is fully privatised.

We are seeing, around the world now, cross-ownerships and alliances which mean that we will have a much different international aviation sector to contend with in coming years. British Airways and Qantas make no secret of the fact that they want a seam-free operation, which is all about comparable equipment, similar layouts for aircraft, the capacity to be able to substitute each other's aircraft on particular routes, common spare parts and common catering.

The British Airways international alliance is going to be one of the biggest. We can see what is happening in that respect. It has got a major holding with an American carrier called US Air, and they want to make sure that they can maximise their holding—although they have got some problems with the US government—to give them the world networks that would allow them to virtually operate as one.

It is interesting to muse on what the Qantas role as part of that international alliance might be in years to come. In a commercial sense, probably what is already being looked at is the prospect that Qantas become very much the dominant carrier in the Asia Pacific. We will probably see, in the future, a carrier such as Qantas operating on its present existing routes but also operating on a few of the existing British Airways routes around that Pacific area.

The British Airways network could probably be described as being in the shape of a big dumbbell. By that I mean that we would probably see many of the British Airways services coming out of the UK and Europe and terminating in places like Singapore, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Hong Kong or even Japan, with Qantas picking up the business from those points. The other terminating point for British Airways services would probably be the west coast of the United States, with Qantas taking on the traffic there.

I suggest that further down the line it might make a lot of commercial sense for Qantas to pull out of some of those European routes on which it is operating at the moment. We all rather look forward to the investigation by the Trade Practices Commission into the common fare regime that is being talked about between British Airways and Qantas. If that is approved, in an Australian sense, it will obviously make a lot sense for them to go into this seamless service. There may be opportunities for other Australian carriers, and especially specialist carriers, to pick off some of those routes.

The member for Watson, before he sat down, was talking about the situation on the Athens route. Qantas always said that it could not make money on the Athens route, so it amazed me that every other Asian carrier managed to get a few through services to Athens out of Australia as quickly as they possibly could when those services came off.

Athens is a case in point. When one looks at the figures for the physical traffic that operates between Australia and Greece, one finds that they are not inconsiderable, and one would think that there would be room there for a specialist operation. If Qantas, for example, decided to pull off Rome, there would be some tremendous traffic there. There might be opportunities for another Australian carrier to start moving into that area.

This really is going to have to be determined in the future by the IASC. With the combination of the incredible growth of inbound tourism and the potential growth of inbound tourism, plus the changing nature of the international aviation business, it is important that Australia does maintain a competitive edge.

The member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), was talking earlier about the need for competition on international routes. I just flag that one of the things that worries me is that if we are not absolutely careful, and if the IASC does not have the full independence and flexibility to grant rights for additional carriers, we could end up going the way that Great Britain has gone in terms of its semi-deregulation of the international aviation process. It is very interesting to look at the UK figures. Prior to the liberalisation of the international aviation regime, British Airways as the national carrier had 80 per cent of the business out of Britain. Ten years down the track, British Airways now has 87 per cent of the business. One wonders whether or not that has necessarily been good for the British travelling public.

I think the last thing that we really would want to see happen in Australia is a return to the `heavenly twins' that we had in the pre-deregulation days, when we had two carriers wandering around the domestic skies and setting up the business. I would not suggest that this is going to happen in an international sense, but I think we have got to flag it. The last thing that we would want would be a suggestion that maybe we have the possibility of only two carriers which could block out all other competition in an international sense. That will not necessarily happen, but it may happen in this particular part of the Pacific. We have already heard about what is going to happen when competition is introduced to the Hong Kong route, and about an $800 fare that can be bought from any travel agency at the moment on two of the operators on that particular route.

In that respect I would also like to raise the issue of the New Zealand situation. The member for Watson was quite off-beam when he started talking about what the common aviation market was all about. The proposed agreement between Australia and New Zealand included the right for any Australian or New Zealand carrier to fly between the two countries or within the two countries, and there was to be really no restriction. The honourable member was not strictly correct in saying that New Zealand did not meet the obligations of the memorandum of understanding that he quoted. The press on both sides of the Tasman have publicised quite fulsomely the fact that, when it came to the common boundaries and the immigration arrangements, it was the Australian officials who told New Zealand in April this year that they were not terribly concerned about what was going on. The reality of this whole debacle is partly about the Qantas float, but it is also partly about the present situation with Ansett. That aside, it would appear that the common aviation market is being put on hold and Air New Zealand has promised to go and have another look at the Ansett books to see whether there might be some room to move there.

I also stress that it may cause some tremendous problems in New Zealand in terms of the trade practices legislation there if Air New Zealand has a holding in the parent company of Ansett New Zealand. I suppose that that might be the next issue that will come up and have to be overcome. But the concept of the common aviation market, and the right of any Australian carrier or any New Zealand carrier to operate between the two countries and within those two countries, has enormous potential. Particularly for Australia, there is enormous potential to foster that competition and Australia really has a very great advantage in being able to open up completely new destinations.

The Deputy National Party Whip, the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), was here before. I know the tremendous enthusiasm he has had, for example, for some charter flights that were operated between New Zealand and Coffs Harbour. Basically what we are talking about is the right for any carrier to be able to fly between any two ports in Australia and New Zealand. I would have thought that it would be very much to the advantage of places like Coffs Harbour—certainly, in my own neck of the woods, the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast of Queensland and North Queensland—to have this open slather capacity that could be operated by aircraft of the right size. Such aircraft are contained in the fleets of both countries, and we could have seen some tremendous advantages for the regional areas of Australia. Hopefully we actually will see some tremendous advantages in the regional areas of Australia when this free market is ultimately opened up.

While it has got very little to do with this bill, may I also say that I was surprised at the attitude that was taken by the government. I would have thought that some very great advantages would come about should Air New Zealand—and I stress `should Air New Zealand'—ultimately decide that it would operate some limited domestic services within Australia.

I think the actual bill itself is terribly important in as much as one of its prime focuses, apart from the flexibility it provides, is the focus on Taiwan and the fact that now at last there is a relatively easy procedure to go through to make sure that that capacity is available. In Taiwan this year the government is requiring 20 per cent of the population to go overseas for a holiday. That is almost by government decree. It has been decreed for two reasons: apart from the fact that the people of Taiwan work pretty hard, the environment there is not always conducive to holiday making. In fact, if people want to go to a beach resort in a tiny place like Taipei, they do not need a cut lunch and a thermos of Milo to get there—they have to take at least a full day of supplies because the road system is so full that people just cannot get around the island and get to those holiday resorts.

They are also in the most magnificent situation of having an excess in terms of their balance of trade. They have billions and billions of dollars that are getting a bit embarrassing and they see that as one way of getting people to go overseas and to spend a few dollars. After years and years of debate about whether or not we should open up an air route to Taipei, as soon as we did—bang!—everything was full. Sure, there is some seasonality about it and, sure, this particular bill is going to give that flexibility to be able to put on those extra flights; but I am somewhat concerned that we may not have got the full advantage of that Taipei traffic. In the last 12 months or so we have not necessarily had that full flexibility available in those peak times to bring in those tremendous numbers of people who want to come to Australia.

Yes, they are going around Asia but they have been going around Asia for some years and Australia is certainly seen as an exciting new and environmentally friendly and safe destination. The potential out of Taipei is absolutely enormous. When we look at the expenditure patterns of tourists from Taipei—forget their air fares and forget what they spend in their hotel accommodation—they are spending in excess of $200 per head per day while they are here. It is not bad if we can get 100,000-plus Taiwanese coming in here and putting that sort of money into our economy. It is not only into our retail system but into our manufacturing and rural systems as well. I often think that we do not fully recognise just what the international tourism business is all about in terms of its capacity to be able to provide wealth for Australia. Obviously, international tourism is going to be very much determined on the price of fares into Australia and the capacity of Australia to take that business. It all starts with airline services.

So the commission the IASC has got is going to be a very important one for the future of Australia. It is going to be a very important one for the remainder of this decade while we have this settling-down period when we find out what the new complex of international airline arrangements is all about. We want to make sure, through the IASC, that we do have the capacity for Australian carriers to be able to meet the demand and that we have no artificial inhibitions to new international carriers in Australia starting up to service some of that particular traffic.

At the end of the day, I just say this: I think the IASC has a huge social obligation. I know that I have mentioned this in speeches for years and years but it is a fact of life. Every time we get a net increase of 25,000 international tourists coming into Australia, we create another 1,400 jobs—25,000 net increase, another 1,400 jobs. That is pretty important in terms of what we are going to provide for our kids and their kids in the future. The tourist industry is going to be a major factor in the creation of new employment in Australia. One of the things that the IASC must realise is that it has a very vital role in making sure that we can maximise that inbound tourist traffic and, by doing that, maximise future jobs for our kids.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members who have spoken in the debate. It is pleasing to see in the context of a debate as important as this, about one of our key industries and the impacts it has, that there has been such broad ranging support. I commend the bill to the house.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Elliott)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIFE INSURANCE BILL 1994Cognate bill:LIFE INSURANCE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND REPEALS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 30 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Life Insurance Bill 1994 introduces a modern regulatory framework for the life insurance industry. It represents the first major reform of the life insurance law since the then Treasurer, Ben Chifley, introduced the Life Insurance Act of 1945. That act will be superseded by this bill.

PARA.TAB: Today, as in 1945, the life insurance industry makes a significant economic and social contribution to Australia. Thousands of households and businesses rely on savings and risk products sold by life companies. The life industry has assets over $115 billion and plays a key role in our financial system. It also makes an important contribution to raising and managing our national savings.

However, the life industry operates in an environment which is considerably different from conditions prevailing in 1945. There have been remarkable technological developments, financial deregulation, advances in actuarial and accounting methods and innovation in life product design during that time. This is why we need a completely new regulatory regime to deal with this industry. I turn to the provisions, first of all in the prudential measures.

The Life Insurance Bill 1994 will result in a clearer, stronger and more modern regulatory regime which substantially strengthens the prudential controls. It aims to protect policy owners within the framework of a well managed and competitive and financially sound life insurance industry. The measures proposed in this bill will make the industry more accountable to consumers, the financial community and the industry regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The bill ensures that life companies themselves will take a more active and responsible role in supervising their activities and operations. Directors, auditors and actuaries of life companies will have increased responsibilities.

Directors will be required to ensure that the life company gives priority to policy owner interests when dealing with statutory fund assets. They will also be required to form an audit committee to monitor financial reporting, internal management and financial controls. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be given clear supervisory powers over products developed during the past decade as well as new products developed in the future.

Life companies will be required to meet upgraded solvency and capital adequacy standards demonstrating that they are financially sound, able to meet their existing obligations, and in a position to continue as a going concern. The Life Insurance Actuarial Standards Board will be established to develop these and other actuarial standards relevant to life company prudential controls. More comprehensive and meaningful financial statements will make each

SPEECH.PARA: life company's solvency position and underlying performance more transparent and capable of comparison.

PARA.TAB: To more effectively supervise the life insurance industry, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be given additional powers and resources to:

SPEECH.PARA: .issue legally enforceable Rules to life companies covering financial reporting and other matters;
.investigate life companies and obtain statistical, financial and asset information from them; and
.initiate judicial management processes in the event of fraud or where the financial viability of a life company is at stake.

Amendments which I will move during this debate will update the provisions relating to policies in part IV of the Life Insurance Act 1945. The remaining amendments are technical refinements resulting from a process of two way consultation with the industry.

PARA.TAB: This has taken place since the bill was first presented and highlights the virtue of the consultative approach that has been taken in respect of ensuring that these measures come before the House with very strong emphasis on consultation with industry and the ramifications and refinement based on the feedback that has come from the industry.

The government originally signalled that consumer measures to complete the package for the new life insurance regulatory regime would be introduced as amendments at the time of this debate. Substantial progress has already been made towards the government's goals of improving information disclosure to policy owners and introducing a code of practice.

To establish the best form of disclosure, the ISC has engaged an independent consultant to interview stakeholders, conduct focus groups and run quantitative tests involving 1,200 consumers. The consultant's report is due shortly, and the new disclosure rules should be finalised in early 1995. Work on the code of practice for life companies is also well under way. The government task force developing the code is currently considering 70 submissions made on a draft code released last August.

The government has also invited the Life Insurance Federation of Australia to form a working group to develop a framework for an industry based system of accreditation of life agents. The working group will also consider whether any changes to the draft code are desirable when it reports next month.

The draft consumer protection legislation, the disclosure rules and the code will be finalised when these processes are complete. The government intends to release draft legislation to facilitate these consumer protection initiatives by the end of this year. This will provide time for public comment prior to introducing the legislation as a separate bill in the autumn 1995 session of parliament.

I believe that process highlights the extent to which the government has taken seriously the need to get the consumer protection issues fully developed. As such, the consultations, which have been welcomed by all sections in those areas, and the research that is being done in those areas, which again has been welcomed by all sections of the industry, I think will mean that we get a very comprehensive package developing out of that process.

This is an important piece of legislation. I want to take the opportunity to acknowledge and thank all those who contributed to developing the new regulatory regime, particularly Bob Glading of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Mr Glading is present in the Committee today. He has had a very long and extensive involvement, stretching over some five years, in these issues. On behalf of the government I pay tribute to Bob both for his work as an officer of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and also for the dedication he has shown to the whole of this work and the very consultative process that has been followed to ensure that, as a result of the package we are presenting in the bills to the House today, we have a world-class system of supervising our life companies. I think that is something that will be well and truly acknowledged.

The measures contained in the bill to promote policy owners' protection and a more efficient life insurance industry will result in additional supervisory costs being incurred by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. These additional resources have been estimated at $1.269 million in 1994-95, $1.053 million in 1995-96, and $1.053 million in 1996-97. These costs will be fully recouped through an increase in the ISC annual levy on life insurance companies. This levy was increased from $28,000 to $70,000 per company from 1 October 1994. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: LIFE INSURANCE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND REPEALS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill 1994, together with the Life Insurance Bill 1994, will give effect to a modern regulatory framework for the life insurance industry. This bill repeals the Life Insurance Act 1945, and makes consequential amendments to the corporations law and other acts.

Amendments which I will move during this debate represent further technical refinements to the bill, following the same process as identified in respect of the previous debate and the consultation with the industry on a range of issues.
The measures contained in the bill are consequential upon the measures proposed in the Life Insurance Bill 1994 and will not directly incur any costs. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Life Insurance Bill and the Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill were introduced into the House on 30 June. The coalition supports them in the form they were in when introduced into the House. The Life Insurance Bill substantially replaces the Life Insurance Act 1945, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) has already said—an act which had remained largely unchanged since its introduction.

PARA.TAB: There are further government amendments to these two bills which I do not intend to canvass, except to say that they have the support of industry parties, as I understand it, including the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, or LIFA. I acknowledge with thanks the information provided, presumably in a timely way, but certainly as early as I suspect was possible, by the parliamentary secretary and his office. The coalition simply has not had a chance to digest that information. No doubt it will receive the deserved detailed examination when the bills reach the Senate. However, at this stage the coalition sees no reason why it should withhold support.

The principal act, which is almost 50 years old, simply does not meet the requirements and expectations placed on it by contemporary society. Matters such as increased prudential supervision and improved consumer protection are aspects of a modern life insurance act that these bills propose.

Among other things, the first of the bills which are being debated cognately—the Life Insurance Bill—will streamline the regulation of life insurance and set new solvency, capital adequacy and financial reporting requirements; increase the responsibilities of directors, auditors and actuaries; increase the powers of the insurance and superannuation commissioner; remove duplicated regulations under the Corporations Law; and establish the life insurance actuarial standards board. The bill does not contain any provisions dealing with product disclosure requirements. However, I think the parliamentary secretary said that the government will introduce amendments which will strengthen disclosure.

The Insurance Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1994, which was debated in this place in the autumn session, made amendments to the Insurance Contracts Act 1984, to give the ISC wider powers to ensure greater disclosure about benefits and early exit penalties to potential superannuants. The government probably intends that any disclosure amendments will operate in a way similar to those clauses in the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1993, which amended several bills, including the Insurance Contracts Act. The Insurance Contracts Act provides for greater disclosure rules for consumer credit insurance, but it also allows for these provisions to be extended to other forms of insurance such as life insurance.

The Insurance Contracts Act provides for greater disclosure rules for consumer credit insurance, but it also allows for these provisions to be extended to other forms of insurance, such as life insurance. On reading the ISC annual report for 1993-94, it appears the ISC is planning to rely on circulars 304 and 305 to ensure that there are adequate levels of information disclosure. The ISC intends to combine this with consumer testing to further refine the disclosure rules and to come up with a number of options for the best means of disclosing total charges and commissions.

To ensure that companies are complying with the circulars, the ISC has been examining the industry's promotional material. As of 30 September this year, 309 customer information brochures and 39 direct response marketing packages have been examined. The ISC claims that most of the material examined shows that the life companies are adequately meeting their disclosure requirements. It was initially planned that the application of circulars 304 and 305 would be consistent with the life insurance code of practice. This code was initially supposed to be released about now, I understand, to coincide with the passage of this bill. However, the code of practice has been put on hold pending the completion of a sample test of three different disclosure options by 1,000 consumers in various industry focus groups.

Before the code comes into effect, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, LIFA, will also examine options for the accreditation of life agents. The government has determined that accreditation will be conducted by the industry, through LIFA, as opposed to a government licensing system. The government's rejection of licensing makes sense, especially in terms of keeping costs and regulation to a minimum. It is also recognition that the life industry should be best able to develop a suitably flexible accreditation system for itself. However, I make the point that many insurance agents and brokers from whom I have received correspondence are very much in favour of licensing and/or some form of accreditation. Their reasons for favouring controls are well-founded, in that they hope to stop unqualified people from providing life insurance and superannuation advice.

They correctly maintain that to allow unqualified people to operate in the industry will invite shonky operators, damage the standing of the industry and have a detrimental impact on the long-term viability of the life insurance market. In the light of that, it is necessary for the ISC and LIFA to make certain, when developing the new accreditation system, that it is effective in keeping unqualified people and organisations out of the industry. However, it must also ensure that the industry does not become too restrictive, so as to knock out everyone except the life insurance agents and brokers. My understanding of the government's position is that all people—as far as practical—giving detailed financial advice will need to be accredited. Therefore, a bank financial adviser will have to be accredited, but a teller handing a superannuation or life insurance information sheet to a customer over the counter will not. That seems perfectly reasonable.

The Life Insurance Bill is important, if for no other reason than that it establishes a basic regulatory framework for an industry of very considerable national importance. The life insurance companies have total assets of some $116 billion, of which $98 billion is tied up in Australian assets. This bill reflects the growing international trend to improve the reporting standards of life insurance companies. Whereas other nations are approaching this issue by means of a more gradual process, Australia is taking the fast track approach. This will be crucial in terms of speeding the rationalisation of the industry. The number of life companies has fallen in the last four years to 51, and this downward trend is expected to continue, due to the capital requirements of this bill as well as because of a shortage of capital in many of the smaller life companies.

I turn now to the detail of the bill. The objective is to protect the interests of owners and prospective owners of life insurance policies, consistent with the continued development of a viable, competitive and innovative life insurance industry. The principal means adopted to achieve this are: restricting life insurance business to companies meeting certain requirements, including solvency and capital adequacy of statutory funds; providing for supervision by the ISC and, where necessary, judicial management; protecting policy owners' interests in the event of winding up; and providing supervision of transfers and amalgamations.

Part 3 of the bill concerns the registration of life companies. The ISC may refuse registration only if the Treasurer agrees and if, in the case of a company limited only by shares, the company's paid-up share capital and share premium account credit is less than $10 million, or such greater amount to be fixed by subsequent regulations.

In addition, registration may be refused if the company's eligible assets, excluding statutory fund assets, do not exceed its total liabilities—other than liabilities in respect of share capital, or liabilities that may be met by the statutory fund—by at least $5 million, or such greater amount to be fixed by regulations; or if, in the case of a company limited by both shares and guarantee, or of a company having no share capital, the company's eligible assets, excluding statutory fund assets, are less than $10 million, or such greater amount to be fixed by regulations; or if the company is unable, or is likely to be unable, to meet its obligations—including non-life business obligations—or is unable to comply with the act; if the company has a name close to that of a registered life company, so as to be likely to deceive; or if the company carries on or proposes to carry on some other business that, in addition to life business, would not be in the public interest. That is the longest sentence I have ever used!

A life company must continue to meet these capital requirements at all times, unless the Treasurer makes a written declaration substituting some lesser amount—such declaration being contingent upon a variety of circumstances.

Part 4, division 1 relates to general requirements for statutory funds of life companies. Statutory funds are established in the records of life companies, and relate solely to the life insurance business or a particular part of that business. A separate statutory fund for Australian investment-linked contracts must be established, as well as one for overseas life business. The requirement is waived if the funds were established before the commencement of this act or if approval has been given by the ISC.

A life company must not mortgage or charge any of the assets of a statutory fund, except to secure a bank overdraft or with the ISC's written approval, which may be subject to conditions and which requires, once again, the Treasurer's consent. Statutory fund assets are not available to meet a contract of guarantee liability, unless the contract was entered into in connection with an investment in accordance with this part.

A life company must ensure that the proportion of liability borne by investment performance guarantees attached to policies does not exceed five per cent. Assets of statutory funds may be invested in any legitimate way likely to promote the business of the fund. Funds may also be invested in a related company which is not a subsidiary of a life company, provided that the investment does not exceed 2.5 per cent of the total assets of the fund and is not in contravention of the regulations. There is no restriction on investing money with a bank by way of deposit; nor is ISC approval required.

Part 4, division 2 concerns the duties and liabilities of directors. The original bill stated that directors of a life company are subject to a fiduciary duty to policy owners, which is the same duty as trustees have to beneficiaries under a trust. The amendments to be moved by the government to the bill now before us replace clause 48 to ensure that a director's fiduciary duty is primarily to the policyholders and that, where a conflict exists between the interests of shareholders and policyholders, the interests of the policyholders will prevail.

Division 3 of part 4 concerns the division and amalgamation of statutory funds. If a life company wishes to divide the assets of a statutory fund in respect of part of the business of an existing fund, application may be made to the ISC under its rules. If the ISC is satisfied the new fund will meet solvency and capital adequacy requirements, the new statutory fund may be approved.

Division 5 of part 4 provides that at least 80 per cent of operating profits—or such higher percentage as specified in the articles of association—which are derived from Australian participating business must be allocated to Australian policy owners' retained profits. The remaining percentage must be allocated to Australian participating shareholders' retained profits.
Division 6 states that Australian policy owners' retained profits may only be distributed to owners of Australian participating policies.

Division 1 of part 5 concerns the solvency standard applicable to statutory funds. With the agreement of the ISC, the Life Insurance Actuarial Standards Board may set a compulsory solvency standard to ensure that assets are sufficient to meet liabilities. The standard may vary for different classes of statutory funds and different companies.

Division 2 of part 6 relates to the financial records and statements of life companies. Signed and audited financial statements, consistent with actuarial advice stipulated in division 5, must be provided to the ISC within three months of preparation, in an approved form. The auditor may accept the actuary's valuation of liabilities. Only suitably experienced, individual company auditors, approved by the ISC in writing, may audit life companies. Of course, approval may be revoked if an auditor performs inadequately.

The life company must notify the ISC, in writing, within 14 days of the appointment or termination of an approved auditor. There must be an audit committee of directors or ISC approved directors of related companies, the majority of whom must not be executive officers, and meetings must not occur without at least two of the members of an audit committee present. The chair must not be the chair of the board of directors of the life company. The audit committee must be empowered to assist the directors to comply with this division, and may be given other consistent functions. Approved auditors and appointed actuaries must be given sufficient opportunity to attend audit committee meetings in order to perform their functions.

Division 3 of part 6 is about appointed actuaries. The appointed actuary must comply with the board's actuarial standard. The Life Insurance Actuarial Standards Board is dealt with in the measures in division 4. The Life Insurance Actuarial Standards Board is established to make actuarial standards for the purpose of this act, which are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.The board has the power to do whatever is necessary for the performance of its function. According to division 6, statistical returns must be prepared each year for each statutory fund, in accordance with the ISC's rules.

Division 2 of part 7 relates to the monitoring of life companies. The ISC may give written notice requiring any information or document relating to the business of a life company, or a subsidiary, to be provided within seven days and one month. The ISC is liable for reasonable compensation should it do so. The ISC may give written notice requiring any record to be provided at a reasonable time and place and may take extracts or copies as required. With the consent of the occupier, and at a reasonable time, the ISC may enter premises where life insurance records are believed to be kept to inspect such documents or to take extracts and to make copies.

Division 3 allows for investigations by the ISC. If the ISC believes a life company has difficulties in meeting its obligations, the commissioner may give written directions on the disposal or otherwise of any asset, for a period not exceeding six months. The direction ceases upon an order for winding-up, or upon the commissioner's issue of a summary of conclusions.

Division 1 of part 8 mandates how and why a life insurance company can be placed under judicial management. The ISC or the life company, subject to one month's notice, may apply to the court for the life company or its business, or part thereof, to be placed under judicial management. On application by either party, the other party is entitled to be heard. The judicial manager has the same power to disclaim property as does a liquidator under Corporations Law.

Division 2 covers the winding-up of a life company. A company may only be wound up on order of the court, following a division 1 application. The ISC may apply for a winding-up order if it is satisfied that it is necessary, following a division 3, part 7 investigation. The court may grant the order if it is satisfied it is in the interests of the policy owners to do so. Under this division, winding-up is to be done in accordance with corporations law.

If a contravention of this act results in a loss to the statutory fund and winding-up is ordered by the court, the directors of the time of the loss are liable for the amount of that loss. If a director is able to prove that the contravention occurred without his or her knowledge, and that he or she undertook due diligence to avoid contravention, then he or she is not liable for the loss. A court may order a liable director to pay the whole or part of a loss, upon receipt of an application from the liquidator.

Part 9 relates to transfers and amalgamations of life insurance businesses. No life insurance business may be transferred or amalgamated except under a scheme confirmed by the court. The scheme must set out the terms of the transfer or amalgamation, and particulars of any necessary arrangements.

We support the legislation, while noting that if substantial amendments are included in those to be moved by the parliamentary secretary later today, we may seek to have them referred to the Senate committee on superannuation for report.

The other bill before us is the Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill. As the parliamentary secretary told us, the bill repeals law introduced in connection with the Occidental and Regal Life insurance companies, which were, at one stage, in some degree of difficulty. Ultimately, the legislation turned out to be unnecessary, as I understand it.

The main provisions of this bill are to amend the Life Insurance Act 1945 and various other pieces of legislation. The bill repeals the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Act 1991 and the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Act 1991. These acts provided for the provision of levies on life insurance companies, to protect policyholders of the Occidental and Regal Life insurance companies. Subsequently, the judicial manager advised the ISC that the levies will not be required.

This legislation follows widespread disquiet with sections of the insurance industry which has existed over quite a few years, particularly amongst the ranks of consumers and of the business community. The industry had developed a questionable reputation for commission-driven sales, which suggested scant regard for the real needs of consumers. The industry has also come to be seen as being secretive and lacking accountability. There is currently little transparency in the activities of insurance companies. The level of information disclosure and financial reporting required of insurance companies is well below that required for other entities under the Corporations Law.

The industry has seen some spectacular failures as well, such as the aborted sale of the Regal and Occidental Life companies. Many of these problems have been attributed to inadequacies in the existing legislative framework and the lack of powers for the industry regulator, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

The Life Insurance Act 1945 is the source of many of these inadequacies. Many of the insurance products sold today simply did not exist when the Life Insurance Act was first conceived. For example, under this act, deferred annuities, one of the most common rollover products, are not differentiated from the other annuity products. The regular reports required by the ISC under the act are, therefore, unable to determine the extent of deferred annuities, as against other annuity products. The financial reporting for the ISC under the act concentrates only on the solvency of the relevant company. There is no focus on company profitability, which means it is impossible to put a value on a life company, or to make comparisons between one company and another.

There is also widespread uncertainty about accounting practices used by insurance companies. For example, considerable debate takes place as to how property investments are valued and about the status of loans made to agents, known as agency development loans. All income received by an insurance company is reported as revenue, regardless of its origins, so that deposits by investors into savings plans are shown as income, whereas a similar deposit at a bank would be shown as a liability. There is no required accounting standard covering the accounts of life insurance companies. I made reference earlier to a number of ISC circulars on the subject, which seek to guide industry practice, but those circulars are not binding.

The bill now before us goes a long way to ensuring that there is greater uniformity of financial reporting in the life insurance industry. The ISC has been doing a great deal to try to establish uniform industry standards. This legislation, along with more practical publications, makes a positive contribution. By all accounts, such efforts have been undertaken in a way which ensures wide levels of consultation. The ISC is to be commended for this.

Increased disclosure is supported by the coalition, while the industry is now largely in support as well. Some quarters in the industry have been reluctant to embrace greater disclosure rules, but the industry now realises that the community will have more faith in it if consumers are made fully aware of what they are purchasing. It seems reasonable to suppose that, if consumers feel that they are receiving a fair deal, the industry can generate a growing market. Mr George Pooley, the ISC Commissioner, has said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am confident that improved information disclosure will benefit not only consumers, but also the life insurance industry. As customers become better informed about the products on offer, competition will increasingly result in product designs, and pricing structures which are more closely attuned to customer needs, and this in turn should generate lasting business.
The life insurance bill goes a long way to bringing the life insurance regulatory framework into line with the expectations which are reasonably held in this the late 20th century.

The ISC is to be commended—and I join the parliamentary secretary in this—for the way it has liaised with industry parties and consumers in formulating the measures before us. As I stated earlier, the coalition supports the bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Life Insurance Bill is a long awaited instrument which goes back many years. The government has been dilatory in the way in which it has approached this issue. Many assistant Treasurers who have been responsible for the area of superannuation have failed to follow through in a substantial way in order to bring about a gradual change. Some of this reluctance is due to the fact that, on both sides of this House, there is a desire for a self-regulatory environment in which the industry can be trusted with its own regulation, and in which it has a code of practice that has the confidence of the Australian community. However, for as long as I can remember, there have been a number of indications that there is a need for the modernisation of life insurance.

PARA.TAB: The decision by the government to bring together the various elements of insurance and superannuation into the Insurance Superannuation Commission at one point is an interesting decision, and one that has not been easy to implement. I remember, in the early days of the ISC, great frustration with the way in which the commission operated in regard to superannuation. It was appalling. The administration was equal to that of the Child Support Agency: huge waiting lists and delays; incredible incompetence; and very poor administration.

Since the areas responsible under Treasury for general and life insurance have been brought into the central body, there has been an improvement in the performance of the ISC. Although I do not believe that improvement is adequate at this point, I commend the final emergence of this type of legislation. However, I have to say that the commission must look to better techniques for servicing the industry than by trebling the levy that it imposes on the industry to cover costs. This appears to be a bureaucratic solution. Whilst the role of the commission has expanded considerably, bodies of this type look too readily to cover their responsibilities by hitting the clients they have charged. There can be no complaint from the clients because they are captive clients and would only complain in dire circumstances.

With those preliminary remarks, I turn to the particularities of the legislation. There is no doubt that the insurance industry, particularly the life insurance industry, has need for the changes I have already mentioned. For instance, the inability of clients to be able to compare products from one company to another is something that has distressed the community. In the area of life insurance and superannuation it has been almost impossible for clients—your constituents, Mr Deputy Speaker, and mine—to compare what a particular company is offering them with a similar package from another company. It appears to be a feature of the industry that insurance companies want to keep secret from their clients the exact details of what a policy holds, so that the client feels captured by that particular insurance company and unable to escape.

From an outsider's point of view, that appears to be the philosophy under which this industry operates. Openness will allow quality organisations to excel, in contrast to the situation where the organisations which are the most secretive are the ones which hold their clients. I suspect that, in future, decisions by investors and by those seeking insurance will be based on merit. I am pleased about that, and I believe that it is a good step in the right direction.

Of course under this legislation all products will come under the supervision of the ISC, and I hope that there is not a desire on the part of the ISC to control or to have a set philosophy.
