I believe that there should be a very open approach: provided that the descriptions are accurate, provided that there is good disclosure on the part of the company and provided that clients understand what is being done by a particular insurance company, I do not believe that the ISC should intervene and prescribe how insurance companies should package their products. The ISC has a supervisory role, but not to the extent of intervention. I do not see this act as giving it the right to intervene and to restrict the free flow of commerce and ideas. In this day and age, when there are inadequate savings by Australians, life insurance is one process whereby people can be encouraged to save.

In these savings packages there needs to be a great deal of creativity and a sympathetic, inventive approach to the needs of people as their lifestyles change and as they experience different needs at particular stages of their workplace experiences. The needs of a single employee, compared with the needs of a person approaching retirement—when the issues of an estate or a family are perhaps being considered—or the needs of a widow, should be carefully considered. When designing a package for a client, the company designing the package should be allowed maximum scope for creativity and inventiveness, taking into account the needs of the client and the insurer, without interference from the ISC.

Just the same, there is a need for clients to understand what they are buying. Too often there is a veil of secrecy and half-truth, which is there to encourage a commitment rather than a comprehension. I want to see both comprehension and commitment on the part of the client, and not just the financial commitment which is so earnestly sought by the person making the sale for the company.

The upgraded solvency in capital adequacy standards proposed in this legislation is welcome. It is a critical feature and it was imposed, to some degree, by the former insurance commission. Though lacking some powers, the commission did its best to ensure that there was adequate solvency and capital arrangements for each firm.

As I go through some of the main features of the legislation, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) can hear that, despite my opening remarks, I am not particularly critical of the legislation. One criticism I do have of the legislation is that some of the improvements have been a little slow. The community needed protection sooner. The government need not have gone to the extent of using this big bang approach to the comprehensive changes to the legislation; a progressive approach could have been used. The government chose to put things on the backburner and then, years after the time when action was urgently required, it came up with these proposals.

I have another criticism of the ISC, or perhaps it is a word of caution. As yet, everything in the garden is not right with the ISC. I want to see a high degree of professionalism and service develop in that organisation, rather than a degree of restriction and bureaucratic control. Its relationship with the industry, traditionally through the separate commissions, has been good. That relationship ought to be retained, along with the additional elements that this legislation imposes. The start up of the ISC was one of the detrimental features of its existence.

The financial statements that are required under this legislation will be more comprehensive and meaningful to policyholders. It is about time this occurred, as reporting procedures have not been accurate. Proper reporting processes are already required of all public companies, but my mind goes back to failures and fraud in this industry. The government has corrected the inadequate reporting procedures in the general insurance industry, and we now have a follow-through with life insurance. It is absolutely proper this should occur. Life insurers need to let their policyholders know exactly where they are putting their money and what the yield is on the policies.

To some degree, the insurance industry, whether it be superannuation, life or general insurance, has been governed by a regime of secrecy, Its attitude has been, `We will not tell you where we have got our dough and we will not tell you what you are going to get at the end of the day. Trust us.' That is not good enough in a society where people do require accurate information, do need to make good decisions and do require, in the early days of their investing life, adequate information in order to make a decision that, in the case of insurance, is a long-term decision. They do not want to get part way through a policy only to find that it is a lemon and that it is difficult to bail out. Things have to be up-front and open, competitive and trustworthy.

The standards board is a good device and one that I applaud. Again, I applaud increased responsibilities for directors. They have to be able to accept that the buck stops with them and they have to be able to stand up at public meetings, at meetings of members—in the case of mutual societies—or meetings of shareholders, and justify their position. I have no problems with that whatsoever. A fiduciary duty to policyholders, or to members, is part of the current regime and should be applauded.

The ISC has additional powers and resources. It can issue legally enforceable rules to life companies. It can approve investigations and initiate judicial management processes. I hope that this is a threat, rather than something that is going to be activated, because I do not want to see interference with this industry. It has been a pretty good industry and it has contributed a lot to Australia. All that we need to do is to have a measure of control, held in reserve by the ISC, so that companies are aware that it can act if necessary.

Too much restriction and control will dampen this industry, even though I would be the first to admit that this legislation is necessary. The opposition certainly does endorse this legislation. The government is correct and we have little to contribute, except that we hope that the government gets on with a proper campaign throughout Australia to devise a comprehensive savings policy, instead of piecemeal legislation. I have said that to the parliamentary secretary on other occasions. I mean it and I will keep on saying it until the government truly develops policies that will encourage Australians to save.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Life Insurance Bill, I do so as a person who, for some years, had an insurance agency. It was a business that I enjoyed very much. It was a very rewarding business to be involved in. I am quite amazed at what is happening in the insurance industry today: where there were some 18,000 insurance representatives throughout Australia, there is now around half of that figure. To some degree, one reason for the fall in numbers is the superannuation issue. But there is also the fact that disclosure has forced the insurance companies to rearrange their management structures. When I had an AMP agency in Mount Isa, we had 17 agents. There are now only two agents working out of that office. That situation has occurred right across Australia. Undoubtedly, there were some agents that the industry would have been a lot better off without, and presumably a number of those people have, please God, left.

PARA.TAB: What is happening now is that the amount of money paid to the agents has been reduced dramatically. The net result of that is that these people cannot cover costs, they cannot stay alive in the industry, so they lose the industry. There is now no-one out there to service the industry. If a person has a query or a problem there is nobody to ring up and no-one to ask about it. There has not been an insurance agent servicing the area that I had, the mid-west region, in any real sense in recent years. Whilst it may be argued that some of the payments were excessive to some degree, it can also be argued that there is no-one servicing the client, and that situation is going to get worse.

There are a lot of people in jobs, particularly in country areas—fencing contractors, shearers, windmill experts, mechanics, builders—who work on jobs and move on. They have to chase the work whenever it comes, and they have to switch jobs a hell of a lot. That is also true in the mining industry. The net result of it is these people do not keep books, they do not know where they were, and their superannuation entitlements are so small that they will vanish and be eaten up by administrative charges. Also, they will have enormous difficulty in simply tracking down where superannuation amounts were set aside for them. I have already had numerous cases—as I think most members of parliament have—of people complaining that they are going to lose the superannuation payments that have been taken out because they changed their place of work on a regular basis.

Whilst some of these changes needed to have been made, there has been a massive overkill and the whole infrastructure of the insurance industry throughout Australia has been damaged. As with most things, the problems are felt far more in the sparsely populated country areas where our servicing costs of driving from town to town are so much higher. So we have felt the problem a lot more than other areas of Australia and will be suffering far more than other parts of Australia. The problem is not, by any stretch of the imagination, confined to the country areas; the problem exists right across the board. It is important that these things be put on the record.

As a minister for some six years of my life, I always had a policy `If it's not broken, don't fix it.' There are a million things out there that are broken. In the 1960s and 1970s this industry was working marvellously well. In return for tax deductibility some 50 per cent—it might have been 20 per cent, I do not recall the figure—of all the money that was put into life insurance companies was taken and put into government securities. This was a good idea in so far as it secured the assets of people who needed to know that there would be money waiting for them when they reached the end of their working life—their retirement fund. By putting money into government securities they had gilt-edged security because the money went into government loans.

That money then became available to the government to farm out into development projects and special help funds—the agricultural banks, the rural reconstruction boards, the Commonwealth Development Bank, the Australian Industry Development Corporation. All of these funds were used to create the Holden motor car. To this very day one of our biggest employers in Australia is the motor vehicle industry, which was commenced partially from funds from the insurance sector of the economy, via the government back to the General Motors-Holden company. That money was then utilised to create an enormous development in this country, which was the building of motor cars.

Similarly, those funds were used to build the mighty Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority project. It is an asset of untold wealth to Australia. The honourable whip of the National Party is here today and he would be able to say that we had a little tiny town out there called Griffith, we had a little tiny town out there called Deniliquin, and they are great inland cities today. The wealth created by the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority came from the moneys invested in life insurance. This was a sensible, coherent scheme. It was a similar scheme to ones which enabled the enormous growth of countries like Singapore, for example, where the superannuation funds have been cycled into development areas.

The old model was an enormously successful model. Someone had the bright idea that things were going to be better, and for the last 20 years in Australia it is hard to point to a single development that has taken place.

I would exclude Queensland from that because of the coalmining and tourism industries there. We applied that principle on a state basis. We took moneys that were invested in Suncorp; those moneys were then cycled out to develop the coalmining industry. Twenty-five years ago we exported no coal at all from Queensland. This year we will export close to $4,000 million worth of coal. Also, the tourism industry did not exist much at all in Queensland 25 years ago. I think we had one five-star hotel in Queensland 15 years ago; we now have probably 30 or 40 five-star hotels in the state. Those things were financed—I will not go into the detail—by the same sort of mechanism as I am advocating today.

We have a problem that the industry is not being serviced. I am not saying that the situation used to be perfect. It was far from perfect. Agents got paid on selling and they did not get paid for servicing accounts. So in a lot of cases they did not service them. In particular, a large portion of the industry was short-term people who would come in for only a couple of years, flog what they could and take off again from the industry. The vast bulk of the agents did not fit into that category—they did service their clients and service them very well. My agent, John Dunn, in Charters Towers, provides an excellent example of the enormous detail, time and effort that such a family puts into servicing clients. They are people who have been in it for two generations. They regard it as their profession and they adopt a professional approach to it. But their margins are getting so slim that I wonder whether they will continue in the industry. They are bright, intelligent people and they can go elsewhere.

The industry, as it is now structured, is not being serviced. Because it is not being serviced, people are not making any effort to look after their risks with insurance against the risk to their life or against any accidents that may occur along the way, insurance for their retirement or even just their home contents insurance. Those things are not being done out there because people simply do not have offices to go to where they can find out how to invest in life insurance and retirement insurance.

Sure, superannuation may look after the bulk of people, but there is still another 10 or 20 per cent out there in industries such as the banana industry, where people regularly change their place of employment and regularly work for only short periods of time. There are the 100,000 or maybe 150,000 fruit-pickers of Australia. They are a very big segment of the Australian economy. Those people often work in the north for part of the mango picking season and move south for a season picking some other fruit. They work for short periods of time at various places and, by the nature of the industry, nothing is being put aside for them.

Similarly, in the building industry the transportable life insurance was one of the most important factors. If we can do it with taxation numbers and those sorts of things, I am quite sure we can do it in the superannuation industry. `Portability' is one of the terms used. If a worker picking fruit at Griffith or Deniliquin puts $100 into superannuation or it is put in by his employer because of legislation, when he moves to North Queensland he simply puts his name down and future amounts go into the one account and keep building up over a long period of time, as opposed to the present situation where the amount is building down for these people.

The other issue, without reiterating, is the old arrangement where the money that was saved to look after people in their old age was put into very useful development projects. Not only did it give the government a vast sum of money to be able to inject into projects like the Holden motor car, the motor vehicle industry in Australia and the Snowy Mountains authority, it also gave people security. They had government security over the money that they were investing. This was the second side of the coin and it is being done throughout Asia today.

Finally, on the issue of fire and general insurance, there was rather a good cartoon in one of the major dailies recently. It had a picture of a man walking backwards and falling down a manhole and it said, `Strangely enough, that is something that is covered by your insurance policy.' We have a continual stream—and this was particularly true when I was a state member of parliament—of people coming through the door. They take out an insurance policy but no matter what happens to their house or car it is not covered because they have all these little out clauses in them.

One case that leaps to mind was on the front page of the Sunday Mail, the biggest newspaper in Queensland, or the Truth, once the newspaper with the biggest circulation in the state. It concerned a family who had their house burnt down. The insurance company, and I do not hesitate to name it as I did in the House at the time, was MLC Insurance. The house was insured. The woman went along to insure it for $10,000. The rep said, `No, the minimum is $15,000, but if it gets burnt down you will get $15,000.' There were three witnesses to the MLC rep making that statement. The house burnt down and she did not get the $15,000 that she was told that she would get; she did not get the $10,000 that she went along to insure the house for; she did not get the $7,000 that she had paid for the house; she got a figure of $2,000.

The company said that its assessor said that the house was worth this amount. I do not know how he figured that out because he lived in Townsville and the house burnt down in Pentland. We produced two similar houses with affidavits saying that these houses were identical. They had been purchased for $15,000 and this house had had $5,000 spent upon it. We were able to prove that with builders. The company still refused to pay. There was a sad sequel to this but it cost the company three per cent of its sales in Queensland, I am very pleased to say, for the next four months.

I am not happy about the aspect I am going to relate, of course. The husband was a drunk, an alcoholic. He had rehabilitated himself and got a job and he dropped his bundle completely. His family were living under a tree in a caravan and he went back on the grog and started belting his wife up. A number of us discussed it and the police discussed it and it was decided that the best thing was to put him into a mental home for a little while until he cooled off. This was to protect his wife and to try to rehabilitate him again. He jumped the fence from the mental hospital and cut his wife's throat from ear to ear. Five little children were left with no mother and no father. That was really a reasonably happy family four months before this ugly event.

I tell the story to indicate the callousness, the viciousness, the criminal irresponsibility of some companies. I do not hesitate to name MLC Insurance and to name that issue. I spoke to the chairman of the board and the general manager on four occasions. I would not say that they were particularly bright. To have left that case there the way they did and to have refused to do anything about it, I thought were fairly foolish sorts of things for them to do. That is not going to bring that lovely woman back to life and it is not going to rehabilitate the husband either.

I use that extreme case to illustrate what is happening out there. There is supposed to be a watchdog over these companies; the watchdog is a farce. The person who is taking money for doing that job should be ashamed of himself and should send the cheque back to the taxpayers of Australia. I rang him on six occasions over that particular incident and I think there were something like 30 or 40 similar cases, all fully documented. In that case, we had two statements from the state Valuer-General's department saying that houses identical to this house had been sold for $15,000, so we knew the house was worth $15,000. The cost of land in that town was $1,000 a block. So we could prove completely that this person was entitled to that amount of money. I am being unfair to the company—it did raise the offer from $2,500 to $3,500 on account of the pressure that we put upon it.

The contracts are farcical and useless. There was no-one working in the insurance industry then—and there is no-one working in that industry now—who would not have loved a standard statutory contract. As depicted in a cartoon in a national daily, the only thing a person is covered for is walking backwards and falling down a manhole on a Saturday! We need some sort of standard form contract to be put out into the marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to make a few remarks in response to a range of issues that were covered in the debate. The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), in particular, gave a very positive speech about the importance of this change to the life insurance industry. Obviously, after 50 years, a new act is going to mean significant change and challenge.

PARA.TAB: In developing the new act, we have tried very hard to get the balance right and ensure that we have a modern, contemporary and complete supervisory regime for the life insurance industry. We have also tried very hard to ensure that it is done in a way which is built on the process of proper transparency in terms of the arrangements that companies have to provide. Firstly, there has to be proper accountability and a better understanding within companies of their obligations and responsibilities, given the range of new products that come on line. Secondly, the regulator has to be well-informed, and in a position to play the proper role of a regulator in the industry and maintain the confidence that proper prudential standards require.

The member for Curtin also talked about some issues that are not directly related to this bill: the process that was followed to develop the accreditation arrangements, the disclosure regime and the consumer issues attached to those. Again, the important thing we are trying to ensure there is that we adopt a model that has the industry, and all those people involved in aspects of the industry, working in concert with us, but recognising the additional responsibilities and the demands that are there at this time.

The member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) referred to the time taken to develop the legislation. The matter certainly has been discussed over a significant period. Rather than make that a debating point, the key thing is that this package represents historic change. It has the support of the industry and a recognition that it needs to modernise. I think that is important in the regulatory framework. It certainly has not been adopted on a model of wanting to have overregulation or restrictive arrangements, but has been developed with contemporary needs in mind and having regard to the range of reports that have been prepared and presented in the past about the life insurance industry and the need to modernise in that area.

Some of those things are highlighted by one or two of the comments made by the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). Again, in many respects, the comments did not actually relate to this bill, but I guess that is not particularly unusual. Nevertheless, we are concerned about ensuring that we do have a model where the regulatory regime is sufficiently comprehensive to give the industry and the community the confidence they need to have in a key industry such as the life insurance industry. At the same time, it is not overregulatory and overrestrictive of the capacity to develop new products, innovations and the things that the member for Mitchell was concerned about.

It is true that in recent years the number of life insurance agents has reduced and the relationship between life agents and life offices has changed. I think most people believe that that was a necessary change in terms of accountability and transparency, particularly if we look at what consumers generally say about that relationship. Consumers are looking for better service and better advice, more follow-up than had been the case in the past for the products they were sold.

All of those changes were fundamentally overdue. We seem to be getting it from both ends a bit in terms of the criticisms. Nevertheless I think what we have here, with the provisions that are in this bill and the amendments we are proposing following further consultations with the industry, and with the package of consumer measures that will flow on early next year and be presented to the parliament for consideration at that time, is a package which means the life insurance industry, along with the comprehensive superannuation provisions that have been previously adopted by the parliament, will ensure we can have confidence in that process. Certainly it will ensure that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission has the proper powers to do its job effectively.

Despite the comments that the member for Mitchell made, both here and in relation to other pieces of legislation on superannuation, there has not been massive growth in the number of officers that the commission has to undertake these roles. The commission has not worked on the basis of needing armies of flying squads of people out there in all of the industry; rather, it has been about getting the balance right, of placing more onus and accountability on the companies as far as the prudential standards are required and about having a proper audit process that can ensure the ongoing confidence in that regulatory regime.

I know from your role in some of these issues, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, you would appreciate the importance of these sorts of provisions. With those thoughts in mind I commend the bill, along with the amendments we will come to in the consideraton in detail stage, to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

PARA.TAB: "60.(1) The allocation of an operating profit of a category of business of a statutory fund must be made in accordance with the following rules:

TAB.TAB: (a)in the case of a profit of a category representing Australian participating business, at least 80%, or such higher percentage as is specified in the articles of association of the company, of the profit must be treated as, or added to, Australian policy owners' retained profits of the statutory fund;

(b)any part of a profit of a category representing Australian participating business and not allocated under paragraph (a) must be treated as, or added to, shareholders' retained profits (Australian participating) of the statutory fund;

(c)subject to paragraph (d), any part of a profit of a category representing overseas participating business, to the extent that such an allocation would not be inconsistent with the articles of association of the company, may be treated as, or added to, overseas policy owners' retained profits of the statutory fund;

(d)if the articles of association of the company require any part of a profit representing overseas participating business to be treated as overseas policy owners' retained profits, at least that part of the profit must be treated as, or added to, overseas policy owners' retained profits of the statutory fund under paragraph (c);

(e)any part of a profit of a category representing overseas participating business and not allocated under paragraph (c) must be treated as, or added to, shareholders' retained profits (overseas and non-participating) of the statutory fund;
(f)a profit of a category representing non-participating business must be treated as, or added to, shareholders' retained profits (overseas and non-participating) of the statutory fund.

PARA.TAB: "(2) The allocation of an operating loss of a category of business of a statutory fund must be made in accordance with the following rules:

TAB.TAB: (a)in the case of a loss of a category representing Australian participating business, no more than 80%, or such higher percentage as is specified in the articles of association of the company, may be taken into account in reduction of Australian policy owners' retained profits of the statutory fund;

(b)any part of a loss of a category representing Australian participating business and not allocated under paragraph (a) must be allocated in reduction of shareholders' retained profits (Australian participating) of the statutory fund;

(c)subject to paragraph (d), any part of a loss of a category representing overseas participating business, to the extent that such an allocation would not be inconsistent with the articles of association of the company, may be allocated in reduction of overseas policy owners' retained profits of the statutory fund;

(d)if the articles of association of the company require any part of a loss of a category representing overseas participating business to be allocated in reduction of overseas policy owners' retained profits, no more than that part of the loss may be allocated in reduction of overseas policy owners' retained profits of the statutory fund under paragraph (c);

(e)any part of a loss of a category representing overseas participating business and not allocated under paragraph (c) must be allocated in reduction of shareholders' retained profits (overseas and non-participating) of the statutory fund;
(f)a loss of a category representing non-participating business must be allocated in reduction of shareholders' retained profits (overseas and non-participating) of the statutory fund.".

"PART 10—PROVISIONS RELATING TO POLICIES
"Division 1—Issue of policies
Alteration of proposal and policy forms

PARA.TAB: "198.(1) The Commissioner may give a life company written notice requiring the company to submit to the Commissioner any form of proposal or policy document ordinarily used by the company in Australia.

"(2) If the Commissioner thinks that a form submitted in answer to a notice under subsection (1) does not comply with this Act or is likely to mislead, he or she may give the life company written notice:

TAB.TAB: (a)setting out particulars of the way in which the form fails to comply with this Act or is likely to mislead; and
(b)inviting the life company to make submissions to the Commissioner on any matter set out in the notice.
(a)at least 14 days have elapsed since the Commissioner gave notice to the life company; and
(b)either:
(i)the company has not made any submissions to the Commissioner; or
(ii)having taken into account the submissions made by the life company, the Commissioner is satisfied that the form in question fails to comply with this Act or is likely to mislead;

SPEECH.PARA: the Commissioner may give the life company a written direction to change the form in the way specified in the direction.

PARA.TAB: "(4) A life company must not make use of a form in respect of which the Commissioner has given a direction under subsection (3), or allow such a form to be used by a representative of the company, unless the form has been changed in accordance with the direction.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Capacity of young persons to insure etc.

PARA.TAB: "199.(1) A person who is at least 10 but has not reached 16 may, with the written consent of a parent or a person who stands in the place of a parent:

TAB.TAB: (a)enter into a life policy on his or her own life or on another life; or
(b)take an assignment of a life policy.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A person who has reached 16 but has not reached 18 has the same capacity to exercise rights or powers in relation to a life policy of which he or she is the owner as a person who has reached 18.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 2—Assignments and mortgages

PARA.TAB: "200.(1) The rights of a person as owner of a life policy may only be assigned under this section.
"(2) An assignment is not effective unless the following requirements have been satisfied:

TAB.TAB: (a)the assignment must be by memorandum of transfer in accordance with, or substantially in accordance with, the form prescribed by the regulations;
(b)the memorandum must be endorsed on the policy document or on an annexure to the policy document that is referred to in the policy document or in another annexure to the policy document;
(c)the memorandum must be signed by the transferor and the transferee;
(d)the assignment must be registered in a register of assignments kept by the life company concerned;
(e)the date of registration must be inserted in the memorandum;
(f)the memorandum must be signed by the principal executive officer of the life company or by a person authorised by the principal executive officer to sign such memoranda.

PARA.TAB: "(3) If all the requirements of subsection (2) are satisfied, an assignment has the following effects:

TAB.TAB: (a)the transferee has all the rights and powers, and is subject to all the liabilities, of the transferor under the policy;
(b)the transferee may sue in his or her own name on the policy;
(c)payment to the transferee of money due under the policy discharges the life company from all liability under the policy in respect of the money;
(d)the memorandum of transfer is conclusively presumed to have been registered in accordance with subsection (2) on the date shown in the memorandum;

(e)as between the life company and a person claiming money under the policy, the transferee is conclusively presumed, for all purposes, to have been the absolute owner of the policy at the time of registration of the assignment, free from all trusts, rights, equities and interests, and entitled to receive the money and give a good discharge for it;
(f)any security over the policy given by the transferee is effective in spite of any trust or any right, equity or interest of another person;
(g)the surrender of the policy by the transferee is effective in spite of any trust or any right, equity or interest of another person;

(h)the life company, in respect of any dealing it has with the transferee, is not required or concerned to inquire as to the circumstances in which, or the consideration for which, the policy was assigned to the transferee or any previous transferee;
(i)subject to section 202, the life company, in respect of any dealing it has with the transferee, is not affected by express, implied or constructive notice of any trust, right, equity or interest.

PARA.TAB: "(4) An assignment under this section does not:

TAB.TAB: (a)make the transferee a member of the life company; or
(b)deprive the transferor of membership of the company in respect of the policy;

SPEECH.PARA: except in accordance with the articles of association of the company.

PARA.TAB: "(5) This section does not:

TAB.TAB: (a)impose on a person under 16 any liability to which he or she would not be subject apart from this section; or
(b)confer on a person under 16 any power or capacity he or she would not have apart from this section; or
(c)render effective a receipt, security or surrender given by a person under 16 if it would not be effective apart from this section.

PARA.TAB: "(6) The rights and liabilities under a life policy are not merged or extinguished, either at law or in equity, merely because the policy is assigned, whether at law or in equity, to the life company that issued the policy.
"(7) A life company is not obliged to register an assignment under paragraph (2)(d) if the company is required or permitted, by another law of the Commonwealth, to refuse to register the assignment.
"201.(1) If a policy is assigned by way of mortgage or on trust:

TAB.TAB: (a)the mortgage or trust is not effective unless it is created by some means other than the memorandum of transfer; and
(b)no notice of the mortgage or trust is to be entered on the memorandum of transfer or endorsed on the policy; and
(c)subject to section 202, the life company is not affected by express, implied or constructive notice of the mortgage or trust.

PARA.TAB: "(2) In spite of subsection (1), the transferee under an assignment may be described in the memorandum of transfer as the trustee or trustees of a superannuation fund.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Effect of notice of trust etc.

PARA.TAB: "202.(1) A life company is not entitled to rely on section 200 or 201 in relation to a matter in which the company has not acted in good faith.
"(2) A life company is not entitled to rely on section 200 or 201 in relation to any trust, right, equity or interest of which the company has received express notice in writing.
"(3) If a life company has received express notice in writing of a trust, right, equity or interest claimed in relation to money payable under a policy, the company may pay the money into the Court.
"(4) Payment of the money into the Court discharges the company from liability to any person in respect of the money.
"(5) The money is to be paid out in accordance with an order of the Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Transfer of policy after change of trustee

TAB.TAB: (a)either:
(i)a policy has been issued or assigned to a person as trustee; or
(ii)a policy has become vested in a person as trustee in some other way; and
(b)the person is no longer the trustee under the relevant trust;

SPEECH.PARA: another person may give the life company written notice that the person giving the notice is now the trustee under the trust.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A notice is to be given in accordance with the regulations.
"(3) The regulations may require that a notice be in the form of, or be verified by, a statutory declaration.
"(4) If notice is given in accordance with this section, the life company may record the name of the person who gave the notice as the owner of the policy.
"(5) When the person's name is recorded under subsection (4), the person becomes the owner of the policy by force of this section.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 3—Protection of policies

PARA.TAB: "204.(1) The rights and interests of a person under:

TAB.TAB: (a)a life policy effected on his or her life; or
(b)a life policy effected on the life of the person's spouse;

SPEECH.PARA: are not liable to be applied or made available by any judgment, order or process of a court in discharge of a debt owed by the person.

PARA.TAB: "(2) Subsection (1) applies:

TAB.TAB: (a)regardless of when a policy was issued; and
(b)in the case of a policy referred to in paragraph (1)(a)—whether or not the policy is owned by the person.

PARA.TAB: "(3) This section has effect subject to the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Protection of policy money on person's death

PARA.TAB: "205.(1) If, on the death of a person, money becomes payable to the person's estate under a policy effected on the person's life, the following provisions apply:

TAB.TAB: (a)except as permitted by paragraph (b), the money is not liable to be applied or made available:
(i)under any judgment, order or process of a court; or
(ii)in any other manner whatsoever;
in payment of the person's debts;
(b)the money may be applied in payment of a debt of the person if:
(i)the person had entered into a contract that provided expressly for the money to be so applied; or
(ii)the person had charged the money with the payment of the debt; or
(iii)the person gave an express direction, in his or her will or other testamentary document signed by the person, that the money be so applied;
(c)none of the following constitutes an express direction for the purposes of subparagraph (b)(iii):
(i)a mere direction that debts be paid;
(ii)a charge of debts on the whole or a part of the person's estate;
(iii)the creation of a trust for the payment of debts.

PARA.TAB: "(2) This section has effect regardless of when a policy was issued.
"(3) This section has effect subject to the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 4—Surrender values, paid-up policies and non-forfeiture of policies

PARA.TAB: "206.(1) Subject to subsections (2) and (3), this Division applies to all life policies.
"(2) This Division does not apply to life policies declared by the regulations to be excluded from the operation of this Division.

"(3) The regulations may provide that this Division applies to a class of life policies subject to specified modifications. If such provision is made, this Division applies to the class of life policies accordingly.
"207.(1) The owner of a policy which has been in force for at least 3 years may request the company that issued the policy to surrender the policy.
"(2) A request under subsection (1) must be in writing.

"(3) Subject to section 208, if the policy owner makes a request under subsection (1), the company must pay to the policy owner an amount equal to the surrender value of the policy less the amount of any debt owed to the company under, or secured by, the policy.

"(4) Subject to subsection (6), if apart from this subsection, the surrender value of a policy at a particular time would be less than an amount calculated, for the purposes of this subsection, in accordance with actuarial standards, the last-mentioned amount is the surrender value of the policy at that time.
"(5) Subsection (6) applies to a life policy issued before the commencement of this Act and still in force immediately after that commencement.

"(6) If, apart from this subsection, the surrender value of a policy under this Act would at any time be less than the surrender value of the policy immediately before the commencement of this Act, the surrender value of the policy immediately before that commencement is the surrender value of the policy for the purposes of this Act.".

PARA.EMPHASIS: Relaxation of company's obligations to surrender

PARA.TAB: "208.(1) A life company may apply to the Commissioner for the suspension or variation of its obligation to make payments under section 207.
"(2) If the Commissioner thinks that such payments would prejudice:

TAB.TAB: (a)the financial stability of the company; or
(b)the interests of the policy owners of the company;

SPEECH.PARA: the Commissioner may, in writing, suspend or vary the company's obligation to pay the surrender values for such period as the Commissioner thinks fit.

PARA.TAB: "(3) A suspension or variation may be subject to such conditions as the Commissioner thinks fit.
"209.(1) If premiums under a policy have been paid in respect of a period of at least 3 years, the owner of the policy may request the life company concerned:

TAB.TAB: (a)to vary the policy so that no further premiums are payable; and
(b)to treat the policy as a paid-up policy.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A request under subsection (1) must be in writing.
"(3) On receiving the request, the life company must vary the policy by reducing the amount payable under the policy to an amount calculated in accordance with actuarial standards.
"(4) The policy, as varied, is to be taken to be a paid-up policy.
"(5) If, when a request is made under subsection (1):

TAB.TAB: (a)the policy-owner owes a debt to the life company under the policy; or
(b)a debt owed by the policy-owner to the life company is secured by the policy;

SPEECH.PARA: the company may either:

TAB.TAB: (c)treat the debt as a debt secured by the paid-up policy; or
(d)in calculating the reduced amount payable under the policy, take the debt into account in accordance with actuarial standards.

PARA.TAB: "(6) If a debt is taken into account in accordance with paragraph (5)(d), the debt is discharged.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Non-forfeiture of policies in certain cases of non-payment of premiums

PARA.TAB: "210.(1) A life policy is not liable to be forfeited only because of the non-payment of a premium (the "overdue premium") if:

TAB.TAB: (a)at least 3 years' premiums have been paid on the policy; and
(b)the surrender value of the policy exceeds the total of:
(i)the amount of the overdue premium; and
(ii)the total of any other amounts owed to the company under, or secured by, the policy.

PARA.TAB: "(2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), the surrender value of the policy is to be worked out as at the day immediately before the day on which the overdue premium falls due.
"(3) Until the overdue premium is paid, the company may charge interest on it on terms not less favourable to the policy owner than such terms (if any) as are prescribed by the regulations.
"(4) The overdue premium and any unpaid interest charged on it are taken, for the purposes of this Act, to be a debt owing to the company under the policy.
"(5) A life company may only forfeit a life policy because of the non-payment of a premium if:

TAB.TAB: (a)the company has given the policy owner a written notice:
(i)setting out the amount of the premium and the day on which it became, or will become, due; and

(ii)stating that the policy will be forfeited at the end of 28 days after the giving of the notice or 28 days after the day on which the premium became, or will become, due, whichever is the later if the amount due to the company has not been paid; and
(b)at least 28 days have elapsed since:
(i)the day on which the notice was given; or
(ii)the day on which the premium became due;
whichever is the later.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 5—Payment of policy money

PARA.EMPHASIS: Probate or administration not necessary in certain cases—a single policy

TAB.TAB: (a)there is only a single life policy under which money is payable by a particular life company to the personal representative of a deceased person; and
(b)the money does not exceed $50,000 or such other amount as is prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph;

SPEECH.PARA: the company may pay the money to:

TAB.TAB: (c)the spouse, father, mother, child, brother, sister, niece or nephew of the deceased person; or
(d)a person who satisfies the company that he or she is entitled to the property of the deceased person:
(i)under the deceased person's will; or
(ii)under the law relating to the disposition of the property of deceased persons; or
(e)a person who satisfies the company that he or she is entitled to obtain probate of the will of the deceased person or to take out letters of administration of the deceased person's estate.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A company may pay the money without requiring the production of any probate or letters of administration.
"(3) A company that makes a payment under this section is discharged from all further liability in respect of the money payable under the policy.
"(4) A person to whom a company makes a payment under this section must apply the money in due course of administration.
"(5) In this section `money', in relation to a life policy, means the total of the money payable under the policy, less any debt due to the company under, or secured by, the policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Probate or administration not necessary in certain cases—2 or more policies

TAB.TAB: (a)there are 2 or more life policies under which money is payable by a particular life company to the personal representative of a deceased person; and
(b)the total of the money payable under the policies does not exceed the amount of $50,000 or such other amount as is prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph;

SPEECH.PARA: the company may pay the money to:

TAB.TAB: (c)the spouse, father, mother, child, brother, sister, niece or nephew of the deceased person; or
(d)a person who satisfies the company that he or she is entitled to the property of the deceased person:
(i)under the deceased person's will; or
(ii)under the law relating to the disposition of the property of deceased persons; or
(e)a person who satisfies the company that he or she is entitled to obtain probate of the will of the deceased person or to take out letters of administration of the deceased person's estate.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A company may pay the money without requiring the production of any probate or letters of administration.
"(3) A company that makes a payment under this section is discharged from all further liability in respect of the money payable under the policies.
"(4) A person to whom a company makes a payment under this section must apply the money in due course of administration.
"(5) In this section, `money', in relation to a life policy, means the total of the money payable under the policy, less any debt due to the company under, or secured by, the policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Death of policy owner who is not the life insured

PARA.TAB: "213.(1) This section applies:

TAB.TAB: (a)if the owner of a life policy dies before the person whose life is insured by the policy; and
(b)either:
(i)the adjusted surrender value of the policy is less than the prescribed amount; or
(ii)the policy is one of 2 or more policies owned by the deceased owner and issued by the same company the total adjusted surrender values of which are less than the prescribed amount.

PARA.TAB: "(2) If a person (the `applicant') satisfies the company that issued the policy:

TAB.TAB: (a)that he or she is entitled, under the will or on the intestacy of the deceased owner, to the benefit of the policy; or
(b)that he or she is entitled to obtain probate of the will or to take out letters of administration of the estate of the deceased owner;

SPEECH.PARA: the company may endorse on the policy a declaration that the applicant has so satisfied the company and is the owner of the policy.

PARA.TAB: "(3) The company may endorse the policy without requiring the production of any probate or letters of administration.
"(4) If subsection (2) applies, the applicant becomes, subject to subsection (5), the owner of the policy.
"(5) Subsection (4) does not:

TAB.TAB: (a)confer on the applicant any beneficial interest in the policy that he or she would not otherwise have had; or
(b)affect any right or interest of a person other than the applicant in relation to the policy.

PARA.TAB: "(6) For the purposes of this section, the adjusted surrender value of a policy is the surrender value of the policy as at the day on which the owner died, less any debt due to the company under, or secured by, the policy.
"(7) In this section, `prescribed amount' means $25,000 or such other amount as is prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this section.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Company not bound to see to the application of money paid by it

PARA.TAB: "214. A company is not, in any circumstances, bound to see to the application of any money it pays in respect of a policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Power to pay money into Court

PARA.TAB: "215.(1) A life company may pay into the Court any money payable by the company in respect of a policy for which, in the company's opinion, no sufficient discharge can otherwise be obtained.
"(2) Payment of the money into the Court discharges the company from any liability under the policy in relation to the money.
"(3) Any money paid into the Court under this section is to be dealt with according to the order of the Court.
"(4) This section has effect subject to the Rules of the Court.

"216.(1) Within 3 months after the end of each calendar year, a life company must give to the Commissioner a statement in the form prescribed by the regulations of all unclaimed money as at the end of that year.
"(2) A life company must not intentionally or recklessly fail to comply with subsection (1).

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty: 50 penalty units.

PARA.TAB: "(3) When the company gives the statement to the Commissioner, it must at the same time pay to the Commonwealth an amount equal to the amount of unclaimed money worked out under subsection (6).

"(4) If, between the end of the calendar year and the date on which the statement is given to the Commissioner, the company has paid any money to persons to whom the amounts were due by the company, the company must give the Commissioner, with the statement under subsection (1), a statement in the form prescribed by the regulations relating to the amounts so paid.
"(5) A life company must not intentionally or recklessly fail to comply with subsection (3) or (4).

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty: 50 penalty units.

PARA.TAB: "(6) For the purposes of subsection (3), the amount to be paid to the Commonwealth is an amount worked out in accordance with the formula:

SPEECH.PARA: where:
`Statement amount' means the total of unclaimed money shown in the statement referred to in subsection (1);

`Money paid' means the total of any amounts paid to persons to whom the amounts were due by the company between the end of the calendar year and the date on which the statement referred to in subsection (1) is given to the Commissioner.

TAB.TAB: (a)unclaimed money has been paid by a company to the Commonwealth under this section; and
(b)the Commissioner or an authorised officer certifies in writing that, apart from this section, the company or a successor company would have paid that money to a person;

SPEECH.PARA: the Treasurer must:

TAB.TAB: (c)cause the unclaimed money to be paid to that company; and
(d)direct the company to pay the money to the person specified in the direction.

PARA.TAB: "(8) A direction must be in writing.
"(9) The company must not intentionally or recklessly fail to comply with a direction under paragraph (7)(d).

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty: 50 penalty units.

PARA.TAB: "(10) If a company satisfies the Commissioner or an authorised officer that an amount paid to the Commonwealth under this section is more than the amount that would have been payable under the policy to the policy owner, an amount equal to the excess is to be refunded to the company.
"(11) Subject to subsection (7), if a company pays an amount to the Commonwealth under this section, the company is, upon that payment, discharged from further liability in respect of that amount.
"(12) The Consolidated Revenue Fund is appropriated to the extent necessary for the purposes of this section.
"(13) The Commissioner must keep a register that contains:

TAB.TAB: (a)particulars of each amount of unclaimed money specified in a statement given to the Commissioner for the purposes of subsection (1); and
(b)particulars of the persons to whom, if this section had not been enacted, the money would have been payable.

PARA.TAB: "(14) The particulars referred to in paragraph (13)(b) may include a person's tax file number.
"(15) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: `authorised officer' means the Commissioner or an officer of the Australian Public Service authorised by the Commissioner for the purposes of this section;
`successor company', in relation to another company (the "first company"), means the company to which the life insurance business of the first company has been transferred;
`unclaimed money' means:

TAB.TAB: (a)all sums of money that have become legally payable by a company in respect of policies; but
(b)in respect of which the time within which proceedings may be taken for their recovery has expired;

SPEECH.PARA: and includes:

TAB.TAB: (c)sums of money payable on the maturity of a life policy which are not claimed within 7 years after the maturity date of the policy; and
(d)any money that the company considers should be treated as unclaimed money.

PARA.EMPHASIS: No deduction in respect of other policies

PARA.TAB: "217.(1) Subject to subsection (2), if a claim arising under a policy is paid, no deductions are to be made on account of premiums or debts due to the company under any other policy, except with the written consent of the claimant.
"(2) The claimant may give written consent to any deductions.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 6—Children's advancement policies

PARA.TAB: "218.(1) In this Division:

SPEECH.PARA: `child's advancement policy' means a life policy issued, before a child has reached full age, by a person other than the child, which contains one or both of the following:

TAB.TAB: (a)provision for payment of a sum to the executors, administrators or assigns of the child on the child's death after the child reaches the vesting age; or
(b)provision for payment of a sum to the child or his or her assigns on the child reaching an age that is at least the vesting age;

SPEECH.PARA: `full age' means:

TAB.TAB: (a)in relation to a life policy issued before 18 May 1989—the age of 21 years; and
(b)in relation to a life policy issued on or after 18 May 1989 but before the commencement of this Act—the age of 18 years; and
(c)in relation to a life policy issued after the commencement of this Act—the age of 16 years;

SPEECH.PARA: `vesting age', in relation to a child whose life is insured by a life policy, means:

TAB.TAB: (a)an age of 10 years or more specified in the policy for the purpose of defining the time at which money becomes payable under the policy; or
(b)the age of 25 years;

SPEECH.PARA: whichever is the earlier.

PARA.TAB: "(2) For the purposes of the definition of `vesting age' in subsection (1), if a policy specifies a date without specifying the age of the child at that date, the policy is to be taken to specify the age that is the age of the child at that date.
"219.(1) Subject to subsection (2), this section applies to every child's advancement policy, whether effected before or after the commencement of this Act.

"(2) This section does not apply to a child's advancement policy effected by a parent, or a person who stands in the place of a parent, of a child in which it is expressly provided that this section does not apply to it.
"(3) Subject to section 220 and unless and until the child reaches the vesting age:

TAB.TAB: (a)the policy is the absolute property, both at law and in equity, of the person effecting the policy or his or her assigns; and
(b)that person or his or her assigns:

(i)in the case of a policy effected after the commencement of the Life Insurance Act 1945 and before the commencement of this Act—is taken to have had the power to assign, mortgage, charge, surrender, vary or otherwise deal with the policy; or
(ii)in any other case—may assign, mortgage, charge, surrender, vary or otherwise deal with the policy.

PARA.TAB: "(4) If a child whose life is insured under a child's advancement policy reaches the vesting age, the policy is taken, from the day on which the child reaches that age, to be the absolute property of the child, both at law and in equity, subject:

TAB.TAB: (a)to any debt owing to the company under, or secured by, the policy; and
(b)to any dealing done by the policy owner before the child reaches the vesting age.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Death or bankruptcy of policy owner

PARA.TAB: "220.(1) This section applies if the person who effects a child's advancement policy dies or becomes bankrupt:

TAB.TAB: (a)during the child's lifetime; and
(b)before the child reaches the vesting age.

PARA.TAB: "(2) Subject to any dealings in relation to the policy effected by the policy owner before his or her death or bankruptcy, the representative of the policy owner holds the policy in trust for the child until:

TAB.TAB: (a)the child reaches the vesting age; or
(b)the child dies before reaching the vesting age.

PARA.TAB: "(3) The representative of the policy owner may:

TAB.TAB: (a)assign, mortgage, charge, surrender, vary or otherwise deal with the policy; and
(b)apply the proceeds as he or she thinks fit for the maintenance or benefit of the child and the payment of premiums in respect of the policy.

PARA.TAB: "(4) The company which issued the policy is under no obligation to see to the application of the proceeds of the policy.
"(5) If the child dies before reaching the vesting age, the money payable in respect of the policy is to be applied in the way in which it would be applied apart from this section.
"(6) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: `dealings' does not include any testamentary dealings;
`representative', in relation to a policy owner, means:

TAB.TAB: (a)if the policy owner has died—the executor or administrator of the policy owner; or
(b)if the policy owner is bankrupt—the Official Receiver or the trustee of the policy owner's estate.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 7—Lost or destroyed policy documents

PARA.EMPHASIS: Lost or destroyed policy—issue of replacement policy document

PARA.TAB: "221.(1) This section applies if:

TAB.TAB: (a)the owner of a policy; or
(b)a person claiming the benefit of section 211, 212 or 213 in respect of a policy;

SPEECH.PARA: claims that the policy document is lost or has been destroyed.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A person referred to in subsection (1) may ask the company liable under the policy to issue to the person a replacement policy document in substitution for the lost document.
"(3) The company may issue a replacement policy document to the policy owner if it is satisfied that there is sufficient evidence of the loss or destruction of the original policy document.

"(4) The company may only issue a replacement policy document to a person referred to in paragraph (1)(b) if the company is satisfied that section 211, 212 or 213, as the case may be, should be applied in favour of the person in relation to the policy.

"(5) If the company does not issue a replacement policy document within 6 months after it receives a request from a policy owner, the policy owner may apply to a court of summary jurisdiction of a State or Territory for an order under subsection (6).

"(6) If, on an application under subsection (5), a court is satisfied that an original policy document is lost or has been destroyed, the court may order the company concerned to issue a replacement policy document to the applicant on such terms (if any), and within such period, as the court thinks fit.
"(7) A request under subsection (2) must be in writing.
"(8) This section is subject to sections 222, 223, 224 and 225.
"(9) The courts of summary jurisdiction of the States are invested with federal jurisdiction to hear and determine applications under subsection (5).
"(10) Subject to the Constitution, jurisdiction is conferred on the courts of summary jurisdiction of the Territories to hear and determine applications under subsection (5).
"222. A replacement policy document:

TAB.TAB: (a)must, as far as possible:
(i)be a copy of the original policy document; and
(ii)contain a copy of every endorsement on the original policy document; and
(b)must state the reason why the replacement policy document was issued.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Notice before issuing replacement policy document

PARA.TAB: "223.(1) This section applies if the amount of the net claim value of a policy at the date the replacement policy document is issued is more than $25,000 or such other amount as is prescribed.
"(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), the net claim value of a policy at a particular time is the amount calculated according to the regulations.
"(3) At least 10 days before issuing the replacement policy document, the company must give notice of its intention to do so:

TAB.TAB: (a)in a newspaper circulating in the district in which the owner of the policy resides; or

(b)if a person claiming the benefit of section 211, 212, or 213 applies for the replacement policy document—in a newspaper circulating in the district in which the deceased policy owner ordinarily resided at the time he or she died; or
(c)in a newspaper circulating in the district in which the company considers the original policy document to have been lost or destroyed.

PARA.TAB: "(4) The applicant for a replacement policy document must meet all the expenses of the advertisement and of the issue of the replacement policy document. The expenses must be paid at the time the person asks the company to issue the replacement policy document.
"(5) After a replacement policy document has been issued, the company must arrange for the following details to be entered in the appropriate register kept under Division 8:

TAB.TAB: (a)the fact that a replacement policy document has been issued;
(b)the reason for the issue of the replacement policy document.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Claim under policy where policy document lost or destroyed

TAB.TAB: (a)a person claiming to be the owner of a policy or claiming the benefit of section 211, 212 or 213 in respect of a policy:
(i)claims that the original policy document is lost or has been destroyed; and
(ii)gives to the company evidence of the loss or destruction that the company considers sufficient ; and
(iii)makes a claim under the policy or makes any other request or claim in respect of it that would result in the termination of the policy; and
(b)the company liable under the policy:
(i)has given at least 10 days' notice of its intention to satisfy the claim or comply with the request; and
(ii)after giving notice, satisfies the claim or complies with the request; and
(iii)records details of its action in the appropriate register kept under Division 8;

SPEECH.PARA: the company is discharged from all liability to any person under the policy.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A notice under subparagraph (1)(b)(i) is to be given:

TAB.TAB: (a)if the person who made the claim or request referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(iii) claims to be the owner of the policy—in a newspaper circulating in the district in which the person resides; or

(b)if the person who made the claim or request referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(iii) claims the benefit of section 211, 212 or 213 in respect of the policy—in a newspaper circulating in the district in which the deceased policy owner ordinarily resided at the time he or she died; or
(c)in a newspaper circulating in a district in which the company considers the original policy to have been lost or destroyed.

PARA.TAB: "(3) The expenses of the advertisement are to be paid by the person who made the claim or the request referred to in subparagraph (1)(a)(iii).

PARA.EMPHASIS: Application of sections 221, 222, 223 and 224 to replacement policy document

PARA.TAB: "225. If the owner of a policy or a person claiming the benefit of section 211, 212 or 213 in respect of a policy claims that a replacement policy document is lost or has been destroyed, sections 221, 222, 223 and 224 apply to the replacement policy document as if it were an original policy document.

SPEECH.PARA: "Division 8—General

PARA.TAB: "226.(1) A life company must have a register of life policies for each State and Territory in which it carries on life insurance business.
"(2) A life company may have such other registers as it thinks fit.
"227.(1) A life company must register each life policy issued by the company in Australia:

TAB.TAB: (a)in the register for the State or Territory in which the policy owner lives; or
(b)if there is no such register or the policy owner has requested that the policy be registered in some other register—in the register chosen by the policy owner.

PARA.TAB: "(2) A life company must register each life policy issued by the company outside Australia in a register for policies issued outside Australia.
"(3) The owner of a life policy issued in Australia may, in writing, ask the company that issued the policy to transfer the policy from a register to another register.
"(4) The company must comply with a request under subsection (3).
"(5) A policy may be transferred:

TAB.TAB: (a)from a register for policies issued outside Australia to any other register; or
(b)to a register for policies issued outside Australia from any other register:

SPEECH.PARA: if the policy owner makes a written request for the transfer and the life company concerned agrees to the transfer.

PARA.TAB: "(6) The owner of a policy is liable to pay to a life company an amount equal to the total of the expenses incurred by the company in connection with a transfer of the policy under subsection (3) or (4).
"228. A life company may only avoid a life policy on the ground that the person whose life is insured by the policy committed suicide if the policy expressly excludes liability in case of suicide.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Condition as to war risk void

PARA.TAB: "229.(1) Subject to subsection (2), any term or condition of a life policy is void if it limits, to an amount less than the total of the sum insured and bonuses, the amount payable under the policy if the life insured by the policy dies on war service.

TAB.TAB: "(2) Subsection (1) does not apply if there is written on the policy document an acknowledgment signed by the person to whom the policy was issued that the policy is subject to the term or condition.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Policies not invalidated by contraventions of the Act

PARA.TAB: "230. A life company's failure to comply with this Act does not invalidate any life policy issued by the company.

SPEECH.PARA: "PART 11—MISCELLANEOUS

PARA.TAB: "231.(1) The Commissioner must, as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year, give the Treasurer a written report on the operation of this Act during that financial year.
"(2) The Treasurer must cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the day on which the Minister received the report.

"232.(1) The Commissioner may, in writing, delegate any power or function of the Commissioner under this Act to a member of the staff referred to in subsection 13(1) of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Act 1987.
"(2) In the exercise of a delegated power, or the performance of a delegated function, a delegate is subject to the directions of the Commissioner.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Operation of State and Territory laws

PARA.TAB: "233.(1) Except as provided by subsections (2) and (3), it is the intention of the Parliament that this Act is not to apply to the exclusion of a law of a State or Territory to the extent that the law is capable of operating concurrently with this Act.

"(2) Subject to subsection (3), the Parliament intends that, in relation to life insurance business (including State life insurance extending beyond the limits of the State concerned), this Act is to apply to the exclusion of:

TAB.TAB: (a)a superseded State Act; and
(b)any State Act amending a superseded State Act; and
(c)any State Act enacted in substitution for a superseded State Act.

PARA.TAB: "(3) Nothing in this section is intended to affect prejudicially the rights, powers or privileges of the owner, or a person entitled to the benefit, of a policy issued before 20 June 1946 (the date of commencement of the Life Insurance Act 1945).

"(4) In this section, `superseded State Act' means a State Act referred to in subsection 8(1) of the Life Insurance Act 1945, as in force immediately before the commencement of this Act, that is still in operation.
"234.(1) A life company must not intentionally carry on any insurance business other than life insurance business.

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty: 300 penalty units.

PARA.TAB: "(2) Subsection (1) does not prohibit an existing life company from carrying on general insurance business if the company was carrying on general insurance business immediately before the commencement of this Act.

"235.(1) If a life company has engaged, is engaging, or proposes to engage, in any conduct in contravention of this Act, of a direction given under this Act or of a condition imposed on the registration of the company, the Court may grant an injunction:

TAB.TAB: (a)restraining the company from engaging in the conduct; or
(b)if the Court thinks it desirable to do so, requiring the company to do a particular act.

PARA.TAB: "(2) If a life company has refused or failed, or is proposing to refuse or fail, to do an act that the company is required by this Act to do, the Court may grant an injunction requiring the company to do the act.
"(3) An injunction under subsection (1) or (2) may only be granted on the application of the Commissioner.
"(4) The Court may grant an interim injunction pending the determination of an application.
"(5) The Court may discharge or vary an injunction granted under subsection (1) or (2).
"(6) The Commissioner cannot be required, as a condition of the grant of an interim injunction, to give an undertaking as to damages.
"(7) The power of the Court to grant an injunction restraining a life company from engaging in conduct may be exercised:

TAB.TAB: (a)whether or not it appears to the Court that the company intends to engage again, or to continue to engage, in conduct of that kind; and
(b)whether or not the company has previously engaged in conduct of that kind.

PARA.TAB: "(8) The power of the Court to grant an injunction requiring a person to do an act may be exercised whether or not it appears to the Court that the person intends to refuse or fail again, or to continue to refuse or fail, to do that act or thing.
"(9) The powers conferred on the Court by this section are in addition to, and not in derogation of, any other powers of the Court.
"236.(1) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: `person affected by a reviewable decision', in relation to a reviewable decision, means:

TAB.TAB: (a)in the case of a refusal under section 85 to approve a person for the purposes of Part 6 or a revocation of an approval given in respect of a person under that section—that person; or
(b)in the case of a refusal under subsection 93(6) to approve a person or a declaration under subsection 94(3) in respect of a person—that person; or
(c)in any other case—the company in relation to which the decision was made;

SPEECH.PARA: `reviewable decision' means any of the following decisions:

TAB.TAB: (a)a declaration under subsection 12(2);
(b)a declaration under subsection 14(5);
(c)a declaration under subsection 15(4);
(d)a decision under subsection 22(1);
(e)a decision to vary a direction under subsection 22(3) or (4);
(f)a refusal to revoke or vary a direction under subsection 22(4);
(g)a decision to cancel registration under subsection 26(2);
(h)a refusal to give an approval under paragraph 31(c);
(i)a decision under subsection 49(1);
(j)a decision under subsection 49(4);
(k)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 52(4);
(l)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 53(4);
(m)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 62(4);
(n)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 63(2);
(o)a direction under subsection 68(1);
(p)a decision to vary a direction under subsection 68(5) or (6);
(q)a refusal to revoke or vary a direction under subsection 68(6);
(r)a direction under subsection 73(1);
(s)a decision to vary a direction under subsection 73(6) or (7);
(t)a refusal to revoke or vary a direction under subsection 73(7);
(u)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 77(6);
(v)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 85(1);
(w)a revocation, under subsection 86(1), of an approval under subsection 85(1);
(x)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 91(2);
(y)a refusal to give an approval under subsection 93(6);
(z)a declaration under subsection 94(3);
(za)a requirement under subsection 115(3);
(zb) a decision under subsection 118(5);
(zc)a decision under subsection 119(2);
(zd) a direction under subsection 121(3);
(ze)a decision to vary a direction under subsection 121(6) or (7);
(zf)a refusal to revoke or vary a direction under subsection 121(7);
(zg) a refusal to give an approval under subsection 125(2);
(zh) a requirement under subsection 131(1);
(zi)a requirement under subsection 132(1);
(zj)a direction under subsection 134(1);
(zk) a direction under subsection 150(1);
(zl)a decision to vary a direction under subsection 150(5) or (6);
(zm) a refusal to revoke or vary a direction under subsection 150(6);
(zn) a direction under subsection 198(3);
(zo) a decision under subsection 216(10).

PARA.TAB: "(2) A person affected by a reviewable decision may request the Commissioner to reconsider the decision.
"(3) The request must be made by written notice given to the Commissioner 21 days after the person first receives notice of the decision, or within such further period as the Commissioner allows.
"(4) The request must set out the reasons for making the request.

"(5) On receipt of the request, the Commissioner must reconsider the decision and may, subject to subsection (6), confirm or revoke the decision or vary the decision in such manner as the Commissioner thinks fit.

"(6) If the Commissioner does not confirm, revoke or vary a decision within 60 days after the Commissioner received the request under subsection (2) to reconsider the decision, the Commissioner is taken to have confirmed the decision under subsection (5) on the last day of that period.
"(7) If the Commissioner confirms, revokes or varies a decision before the end of the period referred to in subsection (6), the Commissioner must give written notice to the person telling the person:

TAB.TAB: (a)the result of the reconsideration of the decision; and
(b)the reasons for confirming, revoking or varying the decision, as the case may be.

PARA.TAB: "(8) Application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of a decision of the Commissioner that has been confirmed or varied under subsection (5).

"(9) If a decision is taken to be confirmed because of subsection (6), section 29 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 applies as if the prescribed time for making application for review of the decision were the period of 28 days beginning on the day on which the decision is taken to be confirmed.

"(10) If a request is made under subsection (3) in respect of a reviewable decision, section 41 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 applies as if the making of the request were the making of an application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of that decision.

"237.(1) Subject to subsections 21(1A) and 23(1) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is to be constituted by a presidential member and 2 non-presidential members for the purposes of a review of a reviewable decision.

"(2) In giving a direction as to the persons who are to constitute the Tribunal for the purposes of a review of a reviewable decision, or for the purposes of a request under subsection 41(2) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 in respect of such a decision, the President is to ensure that each non-presidential member of the Tribunal as so constituted is a person who, in the President's opinion, has special knowledge or skill in relation to life insurance business.

"(3) A non-presidential member of the Tribunal must not sit as a member of the Tribunal for the purposes of a review of a reviewable decision, or for the purposes of a request under subsection 41(2) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 in respect of such decision, if he or she is a director or employee of a company or body carrying on life insurance business or insurance business (whether in Australia or elsewhere).
"(4) An order must not be made under subsection 41(2) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 in respect of a reviewable decision except by the Tribunal.
"(5) The hearing of a proceeding relating to a reviewable decision is to take place in private and the Tribunal may, by order:

TAB.TAB: (a)give directions as to the persons who may be present; and
(b)give directions of a kind referred to in paragraph 35(2)(b) or (c) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Prospectus to be given to Commissioner

PARA.TAB: "238. If a life company lodges with the Australian Securities Commission under Part 7.12 of the Corporations Law of a State or an internal Territory a prospectus relating to securities of the company, the company must give a copy of the prospectus to the Commissioner.
"239.(1) This section applies if a life company or the holding company of a life company:

TAB.TAB: (a)lodges a document, or a copy of a document, with the Australian Securities Commission; or
(b)is given a document, or a copy of a document;

SPEECH.PARA: for the purposes of Part 6.3 of the Corporations Law of a State or an internal Territory.

PARA.TAB: "(2) The company must give to the Commissioner a copy of a document referred to in paragraph (1)(a) or (b) within 7 days after the document is lodged or received, as the case may be.
"240.(1) The Commissioner must keep a register to be known as the Register of Life Companies.
