DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 15 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 will amend six acts coming within the Attorney-General's portfolio. The bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature and makes minor technical amendments to existing legislation. They are explained in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the bill. The proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact.

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Crimes Act 1914 will correct a defect in the recently enacted Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994 which is due to commence on 1 December 1994.As members may remember—and I am sure each and every member here will remember it very well—that act amends the Crimes Act 1914 to provide the Australian Federal Police and members of state and territory police forces with a range of investigative powers in relation to offences against commonwealth laws. Those powers are either conferred directly on constables or require a court order to authorise the exercise of the power.

A number of the provisions in the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994 confer on a court powers which appear to be neither judicial in nature nor incidental to judicial power. I am advised that it is likely that a court might construe the exercise of these powers as being in breach of the separation of powers required by the constitution. This, in effect, would prevent courts exercising Commonwealth jurisdiction from using these powers. The amendments will ensure that the powers in question are conferred on magistrates acting in a personal capacity. The High Court has held that judicial officers, exercising federal jurisdiction and acting in a personal capacity may exercise non-judicial powers without breaching the constitution.

The proposed amendments are uncontroversial. They will not add to or remove powers currently conferred on law enforcement agencies or the courts. Nor will they change any of the procedural safeguards governing the exercise of those powers. Rather they merely ensure that the Crimes (Search Warrants and Powers of Arrest) Amendment Act 1994 will function as parliament intended it would.

The amendment to the Law Officers Act 1964 will allow the Governor-General to appoint a person to act as Solicitor-General during all periods in which the Solicitor-General is absent from duty or from Australia or is, for any other reason, unable to perform the duties of a Solicitor-General. This will allow a person to be given an appointment for a fixed term during which that person would automatically act as Solicitor-General during any vacancy or absences of the Solicitor-General without the need for an appointment by the Governor-General each time that the Solicitor-General is absent from duty. Mr Dennis Rose QC has been appointed to act as Solicitor-General from 7 November 1994. The bill will ensure that Mr Rose's appointment will continue to be effective after the commencement of the act.

The bill will amend parts 5 and 7 of the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 in relation to the enforcement of warrants. Part 5 of the act provides for interstate execution of a warrant (other than one for the non-payment of a lower court fine) issued under the law of a state. There is a possibility that, if a person arrested under an interstate warrant is released or remanded on bail by a magistrate and subsequently goes to another state, he or she might be invalidly re-arrested under the warrant in that state.

The Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 will be amended to provide that, where the arrested person has been so released or remanded, the court, authority or tribunal that issued the warrant must be notified of the release or remand; and that the issuing court, authority or tribunal must notify the police force of each other state which had been notified of the issue of the warrant of the consequences, under the act, of the person's being released or remanded.

Part 7 of the act provides for interstate execution of warrants issued under state law for the non-payment of a lower court fine. It is considered that, unlike warrants under part 5, there is very little benefit in having warrants capable of being executed in more than one state. Accordingly, rather than provide for a notification procedure under part 7 of the act, the bill will amend the act to provide that a warrant under part 7 must be directed to police in one particular state or territory. In addition, the bill will strengthen the existing provision for withdrawal of a part 7 warrant once a person's liability to pay a fine has been discharged. The bill will also clarify the provisions of the act in relation to interstate service of process at an address for service in proceedings.

The proposed amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 will increase the penalties for breaches of the product safety and information provisions of the act to bring them into line with penalties for breaches of the consumer protection provisions of the act which came into force in January 1993; allow the use of penalty infringement notices as an alternative to prosecution for failure to notify the minister of a voluntary recall of unsafe goods; bring the procedure for effecting entry to premises under a warrant issued under section 65Q(5) of the act into line with Commonwealth criminal law policy; and allow the secretary to the department responsible for the enforcement of the product safety and information provisions of the act to accept and apply to the court to enforce written undertakings in connection with matters in which he or she has powers or functions under the act.

The bill will also make a number of minor amendments, including removing gender-specific language, to the Copyright Act 1968. Items 14 and 31 of schedule 2 will make changes to sections 38 and 103 of the Copyright Act respectively, to correct an error that was introduced into the Copyright Act by the Copyright Amendment Act 1991.

As a matter of fairness retrospective amendments should not adversely affect persons who have had their rights adjudicated or who specifically relied on the law in acting as they did. To ensure that result clause 7 of the bill provides that judicial decisions made on the basis of the wording of the existing provisions are not affected by the retrospective amendment. Also protected are actions of persons in reliance on these provisions as they were after the commencement of the Copyright Amendment Act 1991 and before the commencement of clause 7 of this act.
The bill will also remove gender-specific language from the Judiciary Act 1903 and the Law Officers Act 1964.
I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 was introduced into the Senate and amends a number of statutes, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) has pointed out. The coalition does not oppose the bill. I propose to comment on only two aspects of the bill: firstly the provisions relating to the Law Officers Act, and then the provisions relating to the Trade Practices Act.

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Law Officers Act will allow the Governor-General to appoint a person to act as Solicitor-General during a vacancy in the office of Solicitor-General, or in circumstances where the Solicitor-General is unable to perform the functions of the office. This will allow a person to be given an appointment for a fixed term during which that person would automatically act as Solicitor-General each time the Solicitor-General was absent from duty.

There has in recent times been something of a change in the role of the Solicitor-General which I think warrants comment. I thought I might be able to ascertain some information relating to the functions of the Solicitor-General from the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department. Under the Law Officers Act 1964 the Solicitor-General, as an officer, is not required to file an annual report. In the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department there appear to be only two mentions of the Solicitor-General. One is in respect of financial information, where it is indicated that the outlays in 1993-1994 were something over $600,000. The other mention is in the appendices, where the functional statements for the Attorney-General's Department and some portfolio agencies are set out.

In the Attorney-General's Department's report there is no provision of any information at all on what the Solicitor-General has done. I find this rather unusual, and the absence of information is made all the more striking because in the report of the department, and specifically in the part of the report relating to legal services to the Commonwealth, there is extensive reference to the role of the Chief General Counsel and the Office of General Counsel. There we find that the Chief General Counsel, Mr Dennis Rose, QC, has provided high level specialist advice and advocacy services, including making a considerable number of appearances in the High Court representing the Commonwealth. Whether that is on account of the demands on the Solicitor-General or for other reasons is not apparent.

In the functional statements I observe that the Solicitor-General's functions are described in terms which are compatible with the functions of the office set out in the Law Officers Act. Under the heading `Categories of documents' it is indicated that `the Solicitor-General maintains the following categories of documents', and then there are listed certain papers relating to litigious and non-litigious matters, certain matters relating to the Special Committee of Solicitors-General, and a third and fourth item. The fourth one is a miscellaneous item, but the third one is `correspondence, reports and minutes relating to multilateral international organisations'. I find that a bit puzzling. There is the International Court of Justice, and one would anticipate the Solicitor-General would represent the Commonwealth as counsel before that organisation. There are, no doubt, international arbitrations where the Solicitor-General would be expected to act as counsel. But the maintenance of files relating to multilateral international organisations, so broadly defined, seems not to be completely consistent with the role of the Solicitor-General as counsel.

It may be that it is appropriate, in light of the role of the Chief General Counsel and the officers under him, that there be an examination of the role of the Solicitor-General, or at least an examination of what the Solicitor-General does, with a view to determining whether an annual report by the Solicitor-General is appropriate.

I know that the Solicitor-General spends a great deal of time overseas. It may be that the functions of the Solicitor-General are beyond the capacity of one person to perform, in the ordinary sort of way, as they have traditionally been performed. But, in the absence of almost any information at all in the form of an annual report, it is simply impossible to make a comment on that question.

The amendments to the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 are to clarify procedures with regard to the notification and withdrawal of warrants and for the service of process generally. I do not propose to comment on them. The amendments to the Crimes Act are as indicated by the parliamentary secretary in his second reading speech and I do not propose to comment on them. The amendments to the Copyright Act and the Judiciary Act are in relation to language only.

The amendments that caused most concern in the Senate related to the Trade Practices Act and they have since been withdrawn by the government. The amendments sought, among other things, to clarify the powers of entry of officers to premises without warrant to inspect unsafe goods. This aspect of the bill was the focus of attention by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, to which the bill was referred in September 1994. The committee examined the bill and reported in October 1994.

At the committee's public hearing, the committee explored three legal policy issues that arose under the proposed Trade Practices Act amendments. These were the desirability of conferring powers of entry on authorised officers of the Trade Practices Commission, the justification for the proposed increase in penalties for non-compliance with requests for information and documents, and privacy issues which may arise in the exercise of the entry powers.

The bill does not bestow the powers of warrantless entry to premises on officers of the Trade Practices Commission. These powers are provided under the Trade Practices Act itself. The act confers upon the minister, or authorised officers, the power to obtain information, documents and evidence from a supplier relating to goods which will or may cause injury.

The act provides that an authorised officer may enter any premises from which a corporation supplies goods to inspect the goods where he or she has reason to believe that goods of a particular kind may be injurious. The act requires that the power of entry only be exercised where `The exercise of those powers is required without delay in order to protect life or public safety,' or pursuant to a warrant issued under the section.

Under the amendments to this bill that are now proposed by the government, the part of the bill that was to deal with these entry powers has now been dropped. For this reason, I will not comment further on the proposal in the bill to amend the act to clarify these entry powers, other than to welcome the dropping by the government of the relevant part of the bill.

I wish to offer some comments generally on the quasi-police powers given to the officers of the commission under the act.In his evidence to the committee's public hearing, the Secretary-General of the Australian Federal Police Association, Mr Patrick Law, pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: Police officers not only undergo rigorous training in respect of the execution of search warrants but also operate under stringent accountability guidelines. The conduct of police can not only be tested by the courts but by the force's own internal investigation units.
He continued:

Whilst the Association can appreciate the need for legislation to provide for authorised officers with the legislative ability to protect the safety of a person, or to ensure a warrant is not frustrated, it wishes to bring to the attention of the committee the potential problems of extending police powers to non-police. These quasi-investigative organisations do not have the accountability of police agencies and it is this deficiency that exposes those persons working for that organisation to potential danger both civilly and criminally.
He went on:

The Association asserts that those authorised persons or persons assisting them should not be placed in those circumstances which require immediate action to protect life or evidence. This is clearly a police function.

The Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs pointed out in response that authorised officers were accountable under the general provisions which apply to public servants, such as the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, and Public Service regulations, and that they could be the subject of a complaint to the Ombudsman.

PARA.TAB: In the conclusion to its report, the Senate committee stressed that the concerns raised during the public hearing about the extension of certain powers of entry to authorised officers of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs and the Trade Practices Commission relate to the existing legislation and not to the now dropped proposed amendments. This is of concern, because it means that the offending provisions remain in the legislation. The committee went on to say in its conclusion that:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers of warrantless search are intrusive. There is much to be said for the AFP performing these types of functions.
The committee then went on to list the reasons that justify the present arrangement and said:
The Committee records its ongoing interest in scrutinising the issue of the conferring of police type powers on agencies other than police forces.

Certainly it is a matter which should be carefully considered and justified before the practice is extended further. There is also scope to give further detailed consideration to how the powers are to be exercised, how the relevant officials are to be trained and to the appropriate complaint mechanisms which should apply were things to go wrong in the exercise of these extraordinary functions and powers. The committee is of the view that it would be appropriate for the government to review the need for maintaining the provisions in the Trade Practices Act for warrantless searches. The Attorney-General's department has suggested that, with modern communications, the power to get telephone warrants almost replaces the need for warrantless emergency searches.

As I indicated, the committee effectively endorsed the bill, subject to the removal of provisions which are no longer pursued. The committee therefore, in effect, unanimously endorsed the bill in its present form. The coalition does not oppose the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am really pleased that you are actually in the chamber to hear my contribution. I hope my contribution stands up to your distinguished presence.
—I am sure it will.

—I note that the opposition is supporting the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), and that it is an omnibus bill from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). Whilst I want to make specific remarks about some of the proposed changes, I do want to also deal with wider issues of law reform, which I know have a high priority amongst the portfolio ministers from this area. I am sure that these issues are also of concern to opposition members.

PARA.TAB: The proposed bill makes a number of important amendments to the Trade Practices Act, some of which were discussed by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams). It provides for increased penalties for breaches of product safety and information provisions of the Trade Practices Act. It includes a power to make regulations to allow the use of penalty infringement notices, as an alternative to prosecutions, for failure to notify the minister of a voluntary recall of unsafe goods. It brings the procedure for effecting entry into premises, under a warrant issued under section 65(q)(5) of the Trade Practices Act, into line with the Commonwealth criminal law policy. Under this bill, the secretary to the department responsible for the enforcement of the product safety and information provisions of the Trade Practices Act has the power to accept and apply to the court, in order to enforce written undertakings in connection with a matter in which he or she has powers or functions under the Trade Practices Act.

I know it will come as no surprise that many constituents are very interested in this whole area of product warranty and the role of the Trade Practices Act as far as products and services are concerned. The government is committed to ensuring that the Trade Practices Act is up to date and meets community needs.

There is a second focus to the Trade Practices Act which relates to the protection of consumers. The changes proposed under the bill will give weight to the enforcement of compliance with safety measures under the act. The Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Act 1992, which came into force last year, increased the pecuniary penalties for breaches of the consumer protection provisions of part IV of the Trade Practices Act to $40,000 for individuals and $200,000 for corporations.

However, there are various provisions in division 1A of that part to which these pecuniary penalties do not apply and which were not increased in line with the rest of part V. The current amendments will increase penalties for certain offences under division 1A.

One of the very important features of this bill is that section 87B of the Trade Practices Act gives power to the secretary to the department responsible for the enforcement of product safety and information provisions of the Trade Practices Act to accept written undertakings from a person in relation to the powers or functions under the Trade Practices Act. If the undertaking is breached, the authority may apply to the court for appropriate orders, including directing compliance with the undertaking, directing the payment of the financial benefit obtained and directing compensation for any person who has suffered a loss or damage.

The Trade Practices Act is being amended to give the secretary to the department responsible for the enforcement of certain provisions the same power to accept and to apply to the court to enforce written undertakings in connection with matters in relation to which he or she has powers or functions under the Trade Practices Act. Product safety is very important and measures available to enforce consumer safety need to be effective and to reflect the current environment. I strongly endorse those changes.

I said I wanted to talk about law reform. It strikes me that within both political parties we have seen the rise of the supremacy of economics, if not economic rationalists. I wonder, in contemplating the measures that we need to provide citizens so they are able to exercise their legal rights, whether it is appropriate to use tools or disciplines to judge the law—things like micro-economic reform, removing demarcation disputes, or increasing productivity and multi-skilling, to name a couple.

The interesting thing about law reform is that we can measure certain things. If we wanted to, we could get a good measure of unsatisfied demand, that is, people who are unable to obtain funding from legal aid or have their own funds to pursue a legal right. What is the level of un-met demand? I say to the Attorney-General that a very useful statistic to have would be what it costs. We can get what it costs to run the various courts, but how much does that constitute of our GDP? What are the total dollars? I do not know that there has been too much work done there.

There has been some work done in terms of those client services, that is, looking at the roles of solicitors and barristers. It may be said that the proponents of fusion are really eradicating demarcation disputes. Is that really going far enough? Are we sufficiently utilising paraprofessionals? An example of a different way of thinking is perhaps in conveyancing where, in some states now, non-legal people are able to operate, if they are registered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since 1860, in South Australia.

—Since 1860, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General points out, in South Australia. This has a significant impact on affordability. The other thing is that, if one advocates the use of paraprofessionals, one has to ask whether we are sufficiently utilising expert systems in the law, which would be of great advantage. In other words, does a highly qualified solicitor or a highly qualified barrister in every case have to validate advice given to citizens seeking to have answers to legal questions? I suspect the answer is no. What I am trying to suggest is that if we are thinking only in terms of demarcation, if we are thinking only in terms of multiskilling, fusion is not the total answer. It is a welcome answer, but not the total answer, just as the provision of competition amongst barristers and solicitors is welcome, but not the total answer.

PARA.TAB: We then turn to the court systems where legal matters are adjudicated. A few things strike me. For example, it is always going to be very necessary to have eminent and highly qualified judges in our courts, but is it necessary to establish each judicial official with a law library? Does the Attorney-General disclose about every court and about every quasi-court—for example, the Industrial Relations Court—whether people being appointed to these positions are entitled to a law library? What is the cost of providing them with a law library? Are the libraries in their buildings insufficient to meet their needs? Has any judge ever knocked one back?

I want to ask a simple question from the point of view of a working-class member of this parliament. Why is it that judges do not contribute to their own superannuation? How many others in society do not contribute to their own superannuation? What is so special about judges that they do not contribute to their own superannuation? Probably there is a very good historical reason why that may have been so in the past, but I suspect that in our modern day and age this is not a community standard that members of the public would readily accept. In fact, I think it is just like the personal law libraries: members of the public do not know about the fact that judges pay no super.

Then, Mr Deputy Speaker, you come to the issue of staffing. Does every judge really need to have associates, tipstaffs and the use of drivers? Would the quality of the decision making they are involved in, in the 1990s and in the year 2000, be compromised by a lesser staff overhead?

I think I have already commented in an earlier debate that we seem to have a predilection for constructing the grandest of buildings—perhaps, some may say, a touch of hypocrisy for someone standing in this new Parliament House. Let us have the High Court as a grand building—I do not demur there—but does every other federal courthouse in the land have to be so ornate? Again, is it the luxury of the buildings that contributes to the quality of the decision making? I think not.

What is the overseas budget for travel for judges? I do not want to deny the opportunity for learned judges to travel overseas, but how many conferences a year do they need to attend? And is there a minimum number they need to attend every year? Again, given that this money is coming from the public purse—given that this is a legal overhead—can it be argued that these trips are justified. I would be very interested to learn the answer.

Again, I mention this issue of multiskilling and demarcation. We have registrars in our judicial system, and we have a lower court system as well. Are we satisfied that we have the proper breakdown? I will give an example which shows how attitudes to professionals change. I came from the PMG and Telecom. In those organisations we virtually had to have an engineer in every significant management position, until we realised that engineers were a precious professional resource. We realised that we needed to have managers managing, and that we should only utilise engineers in their professional expertise. I pose the same questions: no-one would argue that we need to eliminate judges, but does every function they perform need to be performed by them? Could some functions be devolved to registrars or, indeed, could lower courts, such as the magistrates courts, take on a greater workload?

The other aspect that I will dwell on is the aspect of tribunals. In seeking to reform the law, it is very important that we do not take away people's legal rights. They must always be preserved. We have seen the growth of things like small claims tribunals and many are now advocating alternate dispute mechanisms. Every citizen should have the right to go into court, notwithstanding that people can choose to go through some other process, to exercise his or her legal rights. However, are we satisfied that all those matters that go before magistrates, registrars, or even judges under our federal jurisdiction, need to be there in the first instance? Are there other appropriate forums in which we may be able to conciliate decisions, if not arbitrate the balance of those decisions. We would thus avoid people incurring the expense of going to a magistrates court, or the expense of going into a higher level court. There is much to be commended in this approach.

I will finish on the point on which I started. There is a long haul to go in terms of law reform. I commend the portfolio ministers. I know that they are significantly committed to further law reform. Indeed, I know that the opposition is so committed. However, we may have to use some of the more radical approaches that we have used in other areas, approaches which preserve the quality of output, and which increase productivity. At the end of the day, we are going to move away from the myth that people have legal rights, that is, if a person is unable to exercise a legal right, that person has no right at all. There needs to be a change from the myth of a legal right to the reality of a legal right.

We have a long way to go. Much of the law has priced itself out of reach of not only the battlers whom I am proud to represent, but also the middle class. Some people would argue that the law really is the preserve of the seriously wealthy.

The law has provided a lot of safeguards for the community, and for ordinary people. Lawyers speak with great respect about the role of the law. I understand and appreciate that. In facing the next century it is important that the law adapts to modern needs and demands which are increasing rather than decreasing. Unless this is done, the law seriously runs the risk of becoming totally irrelevant.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I support these bills. Again, I note that the opposition is supporting this omnibus bill. I look forward to learning of the progress that this government is undertaking in law reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I am pleased to sum up the debate briefly. I respond to a couple of points only. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) raised some issues in relation to the amendments to the law officers legislation. I say to him that his comments have been noted and placed on the record and I can assure him that they will be given serious consideration. In relation to the Solicitor-General specifically, can I simply put on the record the fact that the Solicitor-General is not under the administrative control of the Attorney-General's Department. He is a statutory independent officer and so some of the issues that he has raised, whilst they may be of more than passing interest, are not matters which are within the administrative purview of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch).

PARA.TAB: As to the comments of the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), I was fascinated to listen to some of the suggestions he made. I am sure that on reading the Hansard report of his comments others will reach for the smelling salts. The only thing I would like to say to him is in relation to his raising of the question as to why judges receive non-contributory superannuation. I can remember the comments of a former Prime Minister who said that it was an inducement to try to lower the number of lawyers in the parliaments. True or otherwise, I do not know.

One aspect of his contribution I comment on is the question of the extent to which libraries are needed for particular judges. I simply say to him that these days I think a more apt question would be whether computers should be provided and, more importantly, whether re-education schools for potential judicial appointees should not be introduced to ensure that each and every one of the persons appointed to benches in the future is computer literate. That is a tool which, to a tremendous extent, makes a court and a judge a much more efficient facility and person. I conclude my remarks with those comments and commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Duncan)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 14 November, on motion by Mr Langmore:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to comment on the recent report tabled by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Working with the environment: opportunities for job growth. A number of issues readily come to mind where employment opportunities can be created in the environment area. The first one that I mention is the section which relates to policies for sustainable employment growth in the use of less polluting energy sources.

PARA.TAB: A number of opportunities in this area can be utilised. In my own electorate recently an energy program has been developed using co-generation where steam has been used to produce electrical energy. The steam was first created to provide steam for a commercial laundry. That laundry had an excess capacity of steam which was able to be used in the production of electricity. It has generated sufficient power and energy for its own use at the Anne Caudle Centre in Bendigo and it even has an excess capacity which it is producing and putting into the SEC grid network which can be utilised by other users.

Another employment opportunity has been created with the development of co-generation plants, quite a high-tech operation which will require a high level of skills. It is an opportunity that should be developed as it will create some real jobs, not the temporary type jobs that this government is putting forward under its present policies. There is also an opportunity for the development of small hydro-electricity plants. There are a number of streams in Victoria and throughout Australia that could be utilised to produce small hydro plants.

It has been found that smaller hydro plants can be effective. Whilst not being utilised at the point of generation, they can be fed into the grid network, and the power can be taken from the network at the source of the requirement and used. Once again, we are talking about the development of smaller hydro-electricity generating plants which will require a great degree of skill and technical expertise. Of course, these are the sorts of jobs that we are looking for throughout Australia.

The other area that I want to touch on, and which was not mentioned in the report—I did look through it to see whether I could find any mention of it—is the management of the demand of electrical energy in Australia. Demand management is an area that is overlooked. In fact, one of the first questions that I asked when I came to this new Parliament House was about the energy consumed in this building each year. Looking at all of the power consumed in this place—the air conditioning, the lighting, the whole range—the energy bill was running in excess of $3 million per annum. It is not hard to understand that when you look at the excess lighting in this building.

Since I asked that question, there has been an audit of the energy used in this building and I understand that the use of electricity has been minimised. I have not had a recent update of how much it is costing, but one would hope that such things as low energy use appliances, electric motors and low energy lighting can be utilised, and I trust that that has been done in this building. The manufacture of low energy use appliances, electric motors and low energy lighting opens up a whole new field of employment opportunities. There is a whole range of applications which have previously not been considered.

Fortunately, people are now looking at the demand side of electrical energy use as well as the supply side of it. We are getting to a stage where people are looking at their excess use of lighting and are asking how they can minimise energy use with the different forms of lighting. There are also different switches available so that they are able to switch off from time to time. The other area under demand management that has received very little attention is the building and construction design of commercial buildings, factories, high rise buildings and even our residences.

Not much effort has been made to incorporate energy saving design and construction into a lot of our residences. We are still very much at the beginnings of that type of construction. A bit more thought is now being given to how to conserve energy and there are some very innovative architects, building designers and builders who are introducing new techniques and new design features which minimise the use of electrical energy in buildings.

High-rise buildings, most of which are built from steel, glass and a bit of concrete, are massive users of electrical energy. There is a gradual change coming to Australia, whereby people are starting to look at the amount of energy that is being used by those buildings, and they are incorporating new building designs and construction methods. Of course, that is opening up a whole new field for people in the architectural field who are specialising in that area. They are looking at building design, and at how a home can be designed, constructed and put on a site in order to make the home a low energy user. It has a quite dramatic effect.

I will now turn to another topic: a Decade of Landcare, and the national Landcare program. The original announcement of the Decade of Landcare was supported by a $340 million funding commitment, over the decade, for land care and related tree planting and remnant vegetation conservation programs. I must say that this program has been particularly successful and has created quite a lot of work, but there are still a vast number of opportunities for employment in that area.

The local committees which run Landcare could always do with some assistance—in terms of technical expertise, and in terms of just hands-on employment provision—in order to implement the plans that they have so carefully put together and constructed. Most of the Landcare committees consist of local farmers who understand the local environment and know what is required; but, in many instances, they need a few extra hands. In fact, employment opportunities could be created, provided that the money is directed, through the right channels, into those Landcare committees.

I wonder, at times—and mention is made of it in the report—about the promise made by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, about the one billion trees program. I have not heard a progress report from the government on the one billion trees program. I hope they have planted some in South Australia, in the electorate of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford). I hope they have planted some of those one billion trees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I planted some myself.

—The honourable member might even know how many trees have been planted. I doubt whether it is one billion. I think the target was one billion trees by the year 2000. Well, there is still plenty of opportunity for volunteer groups and employment schemes whereby trees could be planted in our landscape in Australia. As members would be aware, through the 1800s and the early 1900s, Australia was denuded of much of its tree cover. That has never been replaced, and there is still the opportunity to green Australia.

PARA.TAB: I would like to receive an update on the one billion trees, and see where they are up to. I do not know who is going to go out and count them all, but I think they are a bit short of their target. I think there is an opportunity there to put money into the development of seed stock and tree stock, to provide a sufficient base to continue that program at a high level and to create some employment opportunities.

The final issue that I would like to direct attention to is LEAP, the landcare and environment action program. I have had the opportunity of seeing some of the fine work that has been done under some of the LEAP schemes. I recently attended the reopening of the old shire offices of the Shire of Strathfieldsaye. The Lions Club is now occupying that building. It was refurbished by a group of young people, under the Landcare and environment action program, and they did an excellent job. Not only did they do a good job; they also gained some very valuable skills which, hopefully, will form a foundation for them in applying for other jobs, where they can further develop those skills.

I think there is scope under those programs to perhaps do a little more on employment creation schemes and channel a little bit more money into those areas. It needs to be very closely targeted, needs to be done probably in conjunction with local government and the community, so that in fact the supervision is there. But it is an opportunity for employment for a lot of young people to develop their skills and go from there. They can go to an employer and say, `Yes, I have done this and it has been successful. If you would like to go and have a look at it, you can see what skills have been put into place in this project.' There is an opportunity there for employment growth under those areas.

The LEAP program may be another program that could be utilised in the control of blue-green algal growth. That is one of the most serious problems in central and northern Victoria and the conditions, particularly during this year, are very conducive to the growth of blue-green algae. I think there are a number of areas of employment opportunity there, in addition to LEAP funding perhaps being put into some of those programs. There is also an opportunity for the government to put further money into small sewerage projects throughout rural areas. It is an area that it has neglected and it is an area that it cannot continue to neglect, because this problem is not going to go away. The blue-green algal growth in areas of central Victoria ultimately finds its way into the streams. Two of the streams, the Campaspe River and the Loddon River, feed into the Murray-Darling system. I know that the quality of the water in the Murray-Darling system is a matter very dear to the heart of the member for Port Adelaide—and to yours too, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the honourable member for Wakefield. A lot of the effluent that is coming from small rural towns in these areas that do not have sewerage is ultimately finding its way into the Murray-Darling system.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we cannot have a sewerage system without water.

—I do not care how it is done. What I am saying is that there are opportunities for employment growth in small water and sewerage projects in rural areas of Victoria. It may well overcome the problem of blue-green algal growth. It may in fact add to the improvement of the quality of water in the Murray-Darling system, and I know that would be of the benefit to residents of your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, and also to the residents of the Port Adelaide electorate. I raise those issues, and there are many others. I commend the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the work that it has done on this report.

—It is a pleasure to have the opportunity to speak to this report on environmental policies which stimulate employment growth from the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Working with the environment: opportunities for job growth.

PARA.TAB: To pick up on some of the matters that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) has mentioned, the committee acknowledged in its report and its recommendations the importance of the program that he mentioned, LEAP. In recommendations 44 to 49 we make some mention of that. Certainly the committee saw that programs such as LEAP, the regional environmental employment program, REEP, and jobskills can be very beneficial. But what we really needed to do was to make sure that in the monitoring of these programs we looked equally at the environmental benefits and the employment benefits. I think that some of the best work that we saw during the inquiry was being done by Greening Australia, which was actually responsible for putting forward to government, in the green paper and white paper process, the proposal for a REEP program.

Looking at what it was hoping to achieve in a program like REEP, one understands that it had taken those elements of the LEAP scheme and jobskills that it thought were important and put them together in a regional sense where the work that could be done under those umbrellas had a focus that fulfilled parts of an overall management plan. That plan not only had those things that we were looking for in the employment sense—skills training, employment experience and the like—but also was able to achieve benefits through repairing and maintaining our land and water. People like Mark Jackson and others who were working with Greening Australia are to be congratulated on the type of work they have done.

In the evidence that they put to us, they quite rightly said that agricultural production counts for more than 25 per cent of our export income. If we are not treating the basic necessities of agricultural production—the land and the water—in an appropriate way, that is causing a great damage to our potential economic benefit. As was said in the various tabling statements in the main chamber on Monday of this week, this report comes at a very important time when the Australian community at large is showing great maturity at being able to see that our environmental and employment objectives do not have to seem to be in conflict, that there is great mutual benefit in looking at them together.

This report also comes at a time when the greens job unit, a joint project of the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, released its report last month Green jobs in industry. As was said in the tabling statements, anything that raises people's awareness about the way in which we can reach our employment objectives, at the same time as satisfying our environmental objectives, is important.

I want to touch on the potential Australia has to take the environmental technology that we are starting to put in place and use it overseas, especially in our region. One of the things that was difficult throughout the course of the inquiry—and it is something that the greens job unit of the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Australian Council of Trade Unions has gone to—is the question of what are environmental industries. The committee took the view that we should not get too hung up on an exact definition.

The International Labour Organisation's classification of environmental industries lists nine categories and gives an idea of the breadth of potential environment industries. Firstly, it lists pollution abatement with respect to air, water and soils—something that the honourable member for Bendigo and I have gone to; secondly, land rehabilitation, including agricultural mining—again, something that the honourable member mentioned; thirdly, soft energies, energy conservation, biogas, biofuel, solar energy and wind; fourthly, transport and communications, substitution of public transport, particularly a role for private transport modes, which is something that Australia has not pursued enough.

It is pleasing that further extension of the light rail system has been encouraged under the better cities program in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, where it will match up with the development for housing on surplus land that was previously used by Community Services, Victoria. Fifthly, under the ILO definition, is water and sewerage works; sixthly, recycling and waste management; seventhly, conservation and forestry, including eco-tourism; eighthly, environmental research and development and training for technology skill development infrastructure; and, ninthly, environment administration and public works employment in regulatory authorities.

As I said in my statement when the report was tabled, one of the things we are pushing through this report is the need to set in place national standards, particularly for air and water, and to see that those are enforced. I was pleased to see in the report of the ACF and ACTU Green jobs in industry that that inquiry had similar outcomes. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), in particular, when he was speaking to the tabling, highlighted one of the recommendations that, if I had had more time, I would have highlighted from the environment committee's report—namely, recommendation (11) that the national environment standard should be outcome oriented rather than process oriented, and stringently and rigorously based on scientific grounds.

At the end of the day, it does not really matter how we reach that end point, but we need to ensure that we are going to reach it. As we have said, and continue to say—especially as a recurring theme for this environment, recreation and arts committee, as we go around Australia—we see in most of our work, and it is put to us by others, that there is a need for national standards. I often get a little frustrated that, because of the nature of the federation and of the division of powers under the constitution, sometimes we have blockages to that goal. It is very important in environmental matters that we see a cooperative effort and cooperative federalism to achieve the outcomes that we hope for.

On the global dimension, the OECD estimated the market for environmental goods and services, based on figures from 1990, at about $270 billion. As the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) mentioned last Monday, that exceeds the estimate for the world aerospace market, which at that time was $250 billion. If you put the figures in that light, that is a considerable part of the global economy.

I pay tribute to the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), and I am pleased that he is on duty here in the Main Committee as Deputy Government Whip. Earlier this year in the chamber, and even before that, he has been somebody who, in the context of the development of employment policies, has been pushing the environmental aspect. He has shown, through various suggestions and the highlighting of overseas studies, the importance of environmental industries for future employment generation.

One of the honourable member's more telling statements highlighted the Japanese experience, where even a ministry like MITI—a ministry which from time to time is looked upon with a great deal of awe—has indeed emphasised the potential for Japan in developing environmental technologies. Those sorts of things are important. Among the things that Japan has to handle is an horrendous waste management problem. If we think Australia has a very bad waste management problem at present, consider the area of land available in Japan for the population. One can easily imagine how difficult the disposal of household waste is there.

I have had the opportunity to visit the Japanese equivalent of a municipal waste dump, which had quite a large incinerator. It did not have to be a very high temperature incinerator, because it was only dealing with household waste, so it was quite environmentally sound. In that case, a relatively small residential development some half-kilometre distant from the incinerator was being fully powered by the incinerator. There was a balancing of a potential problem of getting rid of waste by turning it into a resource base, so that the energy that was produced in the process of getting rid of the waste was in turn used to heat and power local housing. If we can take such an approach to problems, we can come up with solutions that have an economic and employment benefit as well as an environmental benefit.

With regard to our local region and the potential to use Australian environmental technology, AIDAB said in its submission to the committee that something like $A100 million a year of our aid effort is put to environmental purposes. The important thing to remember is that 90 per cent of the aid budget is spent directly in Australia through purchases of goods and services, generating considerable employment locally. That is an area where we can show some leadership by sitting down with countries in our region and offering them the expertise that we have, which has the benefit of addressing a number of their environmental problems at the same time as enabling local economic benefit.

A project that Australians can be very proud of as part of our aid effort is our longstanding involvement with reafforestation in Nepal. That is, I think, now into its fourth cycle. We are not talking only about assisting people in replacing forests that have been destroyed. What we are doing is sitting down with them and assisting them in ensuring that their reafforestation involves sustainable development.

I pay special tribute to the forestry department at ANU, whose people have been involved in this right from the start. They do it now through one of their commercial arms. That leads me to thank the secretariat of the committee once again for its work with this report, acknowledging that the committee secretary, Ian Dundas, is a product of ANU forestry. From time to time I have mentioned that to him, being myself a product of the ANU science department and having had some uncharitable thoughts about foresters at ANU, but in this case they have done Australia proud through their efforts in Nepal.

What we have seen there is attention to environmental benefit and economic benefit—economic benefit to villagers who have the self-management of the programs, given the expertise that the Australians who work with them are able to transfer to them. The ANU foresters are examples of what Australia can do internationally. They are examples, as the honourable member for Bendigo mentioned in connection with the one billion trees and other such programs, of what we can continue to do locally. I hope that our report plays a part in continuing to show that the environment and employment can work together. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence with one of the points that the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) finished with—to pay tribute to the committee secretariat, who worked so well and so harmoniously with the committee in carrying out its tasks and putting together this report. Also I pay tribute again to the committee chair, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), for the excellent work that he did. In some ways it has not been an easy task, but all the comments that were made on Monday when the report was presented to the House were quite positive and the contributions about the nature and meaning of this report were quite enthusiastic.

PARA.TAB: I turn to some of the changes that have occurred. We started the report in May 1993, almost 18 months ago. There has been a significant increase in employment across Australia since that time. While there are more people employed than ever before, we certainly must maintain vigilance, as a government, to develop and create new employment opportunities. Ideally, new employment opportunities would integrate job creation and environmental sustainability. Employment and the environment are certainly two of the biggest issues facing Australia and our future.

I pay tribute to the previous work of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), a member of the caucus committee, in getting onto the government's agenda the white paper and the initiatives that were in that, with the employment and job creation opportunities that the government is involved in and the changes to ensure that the long-term unemployed are assisted through training. I will return to that if time permits.

Employment and the environment are two of the big issues facing Australia and our future. As the polls show, they are the two issues which people still put on their agenda as the most important things. The continued integration of these two issues represents a shift in the way modern society thinks. In years gone by, employment had been generated regardless of the environmental implications. I am glad to say that mostly those days are well and truly behind us, though certainly there is still going to be debate about where the balance falls. I do not think we will ever be able to move away from that debate; no doubt the balance will swing between the two, but by and large what is firmly on the agenda is that everyone agrees there has to be a balance.

There has been an increased focus on the need to incorporate the environmental implications in the current planning and development practices across all facets of the community. It is certainly true in the employment field. Right now we have the debate about the woodchip export licences and the implications for employment within Australia. Many years ago we would not have had that debate. It is good that we are having the debate now. I hope that society does not expect there to be winners and losers from it. If the debate is to run its full course, there will be winners only, regardless of where the balance falls.

In the Whian Whian State Forest, just outside my electorate near Lismore, there is a debate about logging practices in the area, the need for an EIS and the incorporation of Aboriginal input into the management of the sites. The debate in that small area is similar to the debate which has occurred and is occurring across Australia and will continue to occur. In this case, in the forest there are probably 20 or so jobs that the foresters feel are at threat. I think it would be fair to say that, if suitable practices are not put in place, we might be looking at 20 jobs for two or three years at the most. If we come down to a sustainable practice, however, perhaps incorporating tourism, we might be looking at 10 to 15 jobs for ever and a day. When we do the sums, we have to err on the side of caution and look towards sustainable practices.

This report makes 54 recommendations, which I believe provide a map for the future in the areas of employment and the environment. The successful implementation of many of these recommendations will certainly need the support and cooperation of the three tiers of government, the industry sector and the wider community. As committee members would know, this cooperation is already developing. The establishment of a high-level Commonwealth inter-agency group to coordinate and raise the level of interdepartmental cooperation on matters of the environment and employment will play an important role in integrating Commonwealth programs.

Currently, there are many programs, such as the landcare and environment action program, or LEAP, the recently established regional environment employment program, or REEP, Landcare, the save the bush program and the one billion trees program, carrying out excellent work in the environment. I endorse the comments that you made, Mr Deputy Speaker, in your capacity as member for Scullin, paying tribute to Mark Jackson for the work he has done for Greening Australia. He has done tremendous work, particularly on the north coast—I see lots of the work that he does up there—but also across New South Wales and Australia. Because of that work, Greening Australia has been able to have an input into government policy, particularly with REEP.

A more coordinated approach to such programs would streamline their operations and allow greater efficiency on the ground, where the money is best spent. Increasing funding to the Department of Industry, Science and Technology, Austrade and the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau to promote our environment industry will not only reap economic benefits but introduce environmental procedures and practices in developing nations.

I think it is appropriate to mention the possible outcomes of the APEC talks. A lot has been said in the paper about trade and so forth, but an issue that has not been mentioned is the environment. I will be so bold as to suggest that, with the increasing cooperation between nations, as trade opens up and better linkages develop between nations—whether they be cultural or economic—there will be a lot more inspection, a bit more criticism and certainly a greater movement towards better and more sustainable environmental practices in all those nations.

In the past, and, indeed, in the present, a degree of conflict has arisen where there has been criticism inside one country of another and in some ways it has been resented. One of the benefits of APEC may be that we may have more of a family grouping in a global sense. That may mean that that sort of criticism can be directed in a more constructive manner and that there will be a more constructive approach to intellectual and technological transfer. In this way, countries will be able to improve practices and thus the impact on the environment may not be so severe. While the environment was not on the agenda, I am sure that it will be one of the good practices which flows from our movement towards APEC and the cooperation which that will entail.

The promotion of greener production in the industry sector is certainly welcomed. While it is difficult to immediately quantify the benefits from restructuring production procedures, it is important that companies move in this direction and take a long-term approach to cleaner production. Consumers are increasingly conscious of products that are environmentally friendly or use clean production processes. Many of the food distributors, not to mention the manufacturers, are recognising that and moving towards taking that into consideration with their labelling and product promotion.

The increased promotion of energy efficiency and the renewable energy initiatives is important in the reduction of non-renewable energy sources. The recent promotion in my electorate of a Commonwealth initiative, the energy card, generated both strong response and interest. The report also recommends a substantial increase of funding to the national landcare program, a program that has been well supported by the local communities. The allocation of increased funding to the community landcare component will certainly build on the success achieved by local land care groups across Australia.

I have only touched on a few of those recommendations and there are many more that I could discuss. I certainly took the opportunity in the House when the report was presented, as you did, Mr Deputy Speaker, to allude to the recommendation on pollution control and the need for standards in the way we implement those to have them outcome orientated rather than process orientated.

I come back to one of the aspects that I mentioned when I was talking about Greening Australia and Mark Jackson's contribution and that is the notion of green jobs. The north coast of New South Wales is a region that has huge potential for green jobs in a number of areas and there is enormous potential in eco-tourism. We do have World Heritage listed rainforests in the region and on the coastal strip and there is potential in the area of waste management and disposal, recycling and, to some extent, power generation. I might mention one of the icons in my electorate—Mount Warning. Many members may be familiar with this; it is one of the Tweed Valley's most significant landmarks. It has enormous potential as a base for an eco-tourism industry as long as it is controlled by stringent operational guidelines. Certainly we do not need fleets of four-wheel drive vehicles tearing up the area's sensitive ecosystem. What we do need is eco-tourism operators who are knowledgeable about the area they work in and are sensitive to its fragility.
A weekend meeting on the Tweed suggested, amongst other things, a cable car on Mount Nullum and—wait for it—someone called Volcano Man who could actually meet tourists at Coolangatta airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really?
—Volcano Man is not a fellow with a big cigar in his mouth but is something similar to that, I think. That is for the member for Port Adelaide's information.

PARA.TAB: While the Tweed Valley has the potential to become the eco-tourism capital of Australia, I do not think that a cable car, either on Mount Nullum or on Mount Warning, is the way to go. I think some of the ideas that were suggested belong to the sixties way of thinking—or the seventies at the very best. No doubt the discussion that sort of proposition will generate will see it dealt with accordingly.

The recent promotion of the energy card in my electorate, as I mentioned, was very well received. There is a bright future for solar generation in the region. Many people are building houses that are energy efficient. While not directly dealt with in the report, I might allude to the Kingscliff high school students who have recently won a statewide competition which enabled them to put a proposal to the minister for the environment. The proposal that they took to the minister was actually a proposal for an energy efficient school classroom and building. I think they are to be congratulated for the initiative and the foresight they demonstrated.

A further expansion that I would also like to take into consideration is the Mullumbimby power station. It is unique in the sense that it was one of two or three developed in the twenties or thirties that were driven by hydro power. Now that the area is linked up to the grid it is only used at the moment as a back-up for emergency services because of its lower generating capacity. The power station itself is certainly worth while visiting. Apart from the fact that it is useful as a stand-by on an emergency basis, people would be fascinated to see just how far-sighted some people were in the twenties and the thirties.
There are many other areas that I could cover but one that I will mention very briefly is the bush food industry on the north coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are out of time.

—The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has indicated there is a lack of time. The increased use of ecologically sustainable agricultural products and procedures is something which is close to my heart and I know that it is an industry which will develop substantially in the next few years. Overall, I certainly enjoyed participating in the inquiry as I know other members did. That was particularly reflected in their comments in the House on Monday and here today.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Force: Right to Dismiss Members

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 22 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: Did the Minister's predecessor propose in the answer to Senate question No. 1477 (Senate Hansard, 9 May 1990, page 175) that a prerogative right to dismiss at pleasure from the Australian Defence Force co-exists with the statutory right to dismiss only for cause; if so, upon what legal authority did the Minister rely for that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amended answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The answer to the honourable member's question which was published on 4 May 1994 in Hansard on page 279 contained incorrect information in the last sentence. The amended answer is as follows:

Officers of the Australian Defence Force hold appointments at the pleasure of the Governor-General under section 16(1) of the Defence Act 1910 in the case of Army officers, section 12(1) of the Naval Defence Act 1910 for Navy officers and Air Force Regulation 72(1) for Air Force officers. The holding of an appointment at pleasure also provides the power to the appointing authority to terminate that appointment.

It is the practice that an officer's appointment will not be terminated without written notification of the reasons and the officer being given the opportunity to show cause why such action should not be taken.

As was indicated in the answer to Senate question No. 1477, the termination of an appointment is an administrative procedure and should not be confused with the punishment of dismissal from the Defence Force which may be imposed by a service tribunal upon conviction for certain offences under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 30 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What Commonwealth funding was allocated to the Conservation Council of Victoria (CCV) in (a) 1989-90, (b) 1990-91 (c) 1991-92 (d) 1992-93 and (e) 1993-94 from the Minister's portfolio.
(2) By what means does the Commonwealth Government ensure the CCV's accountability for funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has asked that I correct the record in respect of the original answer provided to this question on 23 August 1994. The answer incorrectly showed the 1992-93 grant to the CCV from the Grants to Voluntary Conservation Organisations Program as $92,107 and omitted two grants paid to the CCV from the Greenhouse Information and Education Program Grants Scheme ($32,000 in 1989-90 and $28,000 in 1990-91). The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following amended answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am able to supply basic details of federal Government grants to the Conservation Council of Victoria only from my portfolio.

The Council receives funding from three sources administered by my Portfolio, the program of Grants to Voluntary Conservation Organisations (GVCO), the National Estate Grant Program (NEGP) and the Greenhouse Education and Information Program Grants Scheme (GEIPGS). The GEIPGS (now discontinued) and the GVCO Program are administered by my Department and the NEGP is administered by the Australian Heritage Commission. The Council has also received a one-off grant administered by my Department.
Since 1989, the Council has received a total of $573,588 under the GVCO Program.
Since 1989, the Council has received a total of $75,666 under the NEGP.
Since 1989 the Council has received a total of $60,000 under the GEIPGS.

The Council also received a one-off particular purpose grant of $25,000 in 1993-94 from the Department for coordination of an education project to encourage reduction in urban air pollution and greenhouse emissions from vehicles through better use of public transport.

(2) The Conservation Council of Victoria is accountable to grant administration authorities in the Environment portfolio and therefore ultimately to the Minister. Accountability is secured through the acquittal and reporting procedures developed for each grants program and the exclusion from further participation in programs where acquittal or performance is deemed unsatisfactory. Details of the grants are included in the annual reports of the administering authorities to the Minister which are tabled in Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did he state in a letter to the Minister for Human Services and Health dated 25 July 1994 that service pensions are income tested rather than assets tested.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No, I did not say that service pensions are income tested rather than assets tested.
The letter in question referred specifically to the service pensions paid to a particular veteran and spouse.
In all service pension assessments, both an income and an assets test are applied. Service Pension is then paid under whichever test results in the lower amount of pension.

As the value of the assets held by this couple are within the assets free area, their service pensions are assessed under the income test, not the assets test. Therefore assets held by the couple do not affect the rate of their pension. For ease of understanding, it is customary to refer to the pension as being income tested.
In fact, the majority of service pensions are paid under the income test, and only approximately 3.5% are paid under the assets test.
